“I am hearing…”
“I am wondering if…”


Help transition the client to resolution:
“So you’ve been through a lot and you’re really upset about everything that’s happened before. It sounds like we need to get you in to talk to someone. Would it be okay to get you scheduled for an appointment?”
“The last time you were here, you thought you got the run around and didn’t have time to see the provider. You were really frustrated by all that. How about if we get you scheduled again and see if we can get things resolved?”


Remember the overall goal - client care
If you take a LESS authoritative, LESS controlling, LESS confrontational approach, you actually will have MORE control in the situation.


Responding angrily
Not listening
Criticizing
Being defensive
Arguing with the client
Engaging in power struggles
Ordering the client what to do
Threatening (to cancel an appointment, etc.)
Minimizing the importance of the client's concern
Moving quickly (can be perceived as aggressive)


Saying "You need to calm down"
Trying to be right
Giving commands
"lower your voice"
Arguing with the client
Taking the words or actions of the client personally (even if the client tries to make it personal)
Minimizing the situation ("It is not that bad")
Asking a lot of questions
Asking 'Why' questions
Forcing discussion


Do not express anger, impatience, or irritation
Breathe
Take a moment away, if possible
Never use inflammatory language ("You are acting crazy")
Notice if you are feeling as though you have to rush or feeling like you are stuck if it takes time to get to work through the client interaction
Breathe through it, be patient
Request help, if needed
Don't intervene too quickly or try too hard to control the interaction by interrupting or talking over the client


Follow agency policy
Document
Debrief
Strategies to manage/avoid similar situations in future
What went well? What didn't go well?
Did anything contribute to the escalation?
Did anything help diffuse the situation?
Support for staff, clients, and individuals involved


People are coping the best way they can - our job is to help them find a better way
Requires building trust, creating safety, and creating a trauma informed culture that provides a safe and healing environment
Healing takes more than therapy
Support services can create therapeutic, healing experiences - a place of safety


Screen for trauma history
Deepen attunement skills - learn to interpret behavior effectively as communication
Employ person-centered, strengths-based thinking and language
Provide stability and empowerment
Consider the physiological, psychological, and social risks of physical interventions - choose the least restrictive option as a last resort if somebody is a danger to themselves or others
Prioritize debriefing after a crisis to help foster resilience and develop successful coping skills


Be empathetic and non-judgemental
Respect personal space
Use non-threatening non-verbals
Avoid overreacting
Focus on feelings
Ignore challenging questions
Set limits
Choose wisely what you insist upon
Allow silence for reflection
Allow time for decisions
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Training/De-Escalation through a Trauma-Informed Care Lens.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Strategies for Working with High Conflict Couples
item.description:
Why are couples behaving so badly?
"The average couple waits 6 years before seeking out therapy." (Gottman)
In those 6 years there is:
Build up of resentments
Reinforced bad habits
No boundary enforcement
Erosion of positive perspective
Unconscious bias kicks - assumptions about purposeful poor behavior choices
Missed bids for attention
Depletion of emotional bank account
Never had any positive role models to begin with
From a survey conducted in September 2020:
Increases in substance misuse:
Alcohol (88%)
Marijuana (37%)
Prescription Opioids (15%)
Domestic violence cases increased by 25%-33% globally.
How are these influences showing up in the clients in the therapy room?
Passive/aggressive behaviors
Shut down/Withdrawn/Stonewalling
Withholding Sex or Avoiding Intimacy
Narcissistic Behavior Responses
Gaslighting
Anger
High Conflict
Boundary Crossing
Persistent and Ongoing Flooding
Unwilling to Repair/Apologize/Take Responsibility


How to prepare yourself for the unexpected:
When you open your office door, look for body language and non-verbals.
Have confidence and KNOW that you are the expert in the room. Own it and be brave.


Set the tone at the beginning of the session when you feel something is off.
Let the clients know what you feel when you feel it, and be willing to talk about what is happening. (Do not wait for clients to bring it up or ignore it)
Model for your couples that you are going to talk about it, not let things be passive-aggressive or avoid dealing with hot topics.
Remind clients who escalate that they are not in therapy to repeat old patterns.
Pause and interrupt when you see unacknowledged emotion happening in the room. That is your job.


Don't let your couples argue or verbally explode on each other. They can do that at home for free.
Take Control.
Develop your phrase to create stop-action with clients. Say things like, 'pause, stop,' or call out your client's name, etc.
Be direct.
What is acceptable and what is not acceptable about words or behavior in the room. What you would like your clients to do instead (as for their positive need).
Why it's not okay for them to say or do the thing that you witnessed in the room.
Let the clients know how painful it is for you to witness, so you can't imagine what it's like for their partner.


Keep your eyes on each client in the room. Are you letting one partner high jack the session? Stop the speaking partner and ask, 'What's coming up for you?' Notice if the other partner checks in.
Be mindful of the need to stop and tend to the party not speaking. This is how you keep explosions from getting out of control because you have been checking in on what is happening on the other side of the couch.
Step in for clients when they don't have words and find a way to speak their pain to their partner.
Keep it fair, so both partners feel you are connected with their pain, needs, and wanted outcomes.


Normalize high emotion and disappointment of partner not being able to acknowledge perspectives not because they don't love you. Differences on family of origin, difference in expectations, etc.
Prior traumas and life experiences make it hard for partners to always regulate their emotions in ways they would hope.
Untreated mental health issues impact ability to manage emotions.
Not finished working on the 'Me' stuff versus the 'We' stuff and bleeding over into our relationship.
Discuss the impact of substances and the impact it has on being able to manage emotions.
Gottman Method:
Flooding is expected because partners are experiencing physiological arousal. Utilize pulse oximeters to help validate their elevated heart rate.


Be okay with breaking it up.
Sometimes you need to have one couple leave the room while you do some one-on-one with the other partner.
Let an explosive partner leave if they want. Don't chase them or try to convince them to stay or come back.
Talk about the flooding in the room and share ways to help self-regulate, like taking deep breaths or pausing to find ways to reframe.


You need to be prepared when working with couples that you might need to a break from couples therapy or stop all together based on how the clients present.
This is your call as a therapist to evaluate if working with the couple is contraindicated because of co-occurring mental health, substance, unresolved trauma, suicidal ideation, personality disorders, characterological DV, or anger management issues.
Often necessary to request that clients seek out individual therapy to strengthen their individual coping skills before attempting additional couples' therapy.
Expect your clients to disagree and give you pushback. Attitude is everything in this conversation. Remember, your clients are not your peers, and we often have to make unpopular decisions about the course of care.


When you feel anxious and flooded as the therapist:
Notice where you are breathing.
Plant both feet on the floor. Take your shoulders back against your chair, take a deep breath into your belly, and repeat to yourself:
"This is not my pain to feel."


Get in touch with your client's inner 5-year-old old in the room. What is hurting them, and what is the catastrophe scenario that is playing out for them?
When I de-escalate, so do my clients. When my voice gets softer and quieter, so does my clients, and they can often match my tone and calm demeanor.
Don't shy away from acknowledging they have the right to feel upset, and it makes sense they would be even if their partner does not agree.
Ask their partner to find something they said that they can validate for their partner. Remind them this is not the same as agreeing.
Focus on the behavior or the words you heard.
We can help facilitate meaningful conversation about the emotions each partner is feeling.
Ask the partner who is feeling a big emotion related to their partner to name their emotion. Then talk the behavior they say their partner do or the words they heard them say.
Remind and monitor clients to avoid telling their partner their evaluation of why their partner did it or the mind set they were in when it happened. This often happens and only creates defensiveness in their partner. No one likes to be told how they feel.
Ask for your positive need. Even if the answer is no - you need to hear yourself asking for your need.


Gottman Method Stress Reducing Conversation
10-minutes each partner. Listening for understanding and share emotion. (Not problem-solving)
How do clients know it's working? Does your partner feel hear and understood? Then yes.
Use of open-ended questions to help partners attune, connect, and provide empathy and support.
Questions that allow for each partner to draw out their partner's experience, such as:
"What is this like for you? What do you need? What don't you like about this situation?"
Gottman Method Dreams within Conflict
Asks clients to suspend problem-solving so they can have a better understanding of the childhood stories, values, or core ethics and beliefs that keep their partner rooted in their perspective.
Clients take turns asking each partner a set of questions so they can better experience what it's like to walk in their partner's shoes.
Preparation for compromise like partners who love each other.
Gottman Method Injuries Exercise
Helps partners find a structured and safe format to talk about old injuries in a way that helps facilitate compassion, acceptance, and understand about prior and shared traumas.
Creates awareness and insight about the impact and ways these traumas have shaped the way each partner views their world.
Helps evaluate how clients have learned to cope and survive. Can help some clients gain insight on how they behave in relationships in ways that no longer serve them.
Helps couples therapist normalize and make recommendations of ways those old injuries get triggered in the relationship and behavior changes that might be beneficial.
Gottman Method Appreciations Exercise
Changes tone and energy in session.
Allows each partner to find something positive to notice about their partner to demonstrate holding each other from a positive perspective.
Makes deposits into each partner’s emotional bank account.
Starts conversations about how to do small things often in the relationship for highly disconnected couples.
Way to end session, so couples can ground before leaving in turmoil.


If apologies are made, they are often expressed as implying you misunderstood something but without remorse for poor behaviors
Outside behaviors or the other person is ALWAYS the source of conflict or turn it around on the other person implying they are really the culprit for the issue
Self-doubt creeps in and the partner being gaslit internalizes their lack of hard work in the relationship as the cause of all the problems.
Guilt develops about bringing up issues in the relationship.
It feels very much like the result of narcissistic behavior responses.
The partner who is doing the gaslighting may do so unconsciously to gain control or power in the relationship when they feel out of resources or support.
Manipulation that involves making someone question their own reality, feelings, and experiences of events, in order to maintain CONTROL over that person.


Deflecting the other person by use of lack of acknowledgement, negative body language, and minimizing statements about the other person’s perspective or feelings.
Unwillingness to accept any part of the responsibility for a misunderstanding or conflict.
Intentional implication that the other person is over-reacting or has fabricated a situation in order to create doubt or challenge the other person’s reality
Being cut off from making points, asking questions, or providing input during a disagreement.
No acknowledgment of your hurt feelings when expressed. Lacks Empathy.
Clients are often overly invested in using narcissist label with each other.
Only 5% of population are diagnosable with narcissistic personality disorder
You should be aware that most clients who have diagnosable narcissistic personality disorder are not going to be served in couples therapy and may be contra-indicated.


Gottman Interventions to Bring into Session
Introduces the idea that anything our partner does for us is a gift - they are not required to do so because we are in a relationship with each other.
Softened Start Up:
This is helpful for the narcissistic leaning partner to learn how to be clear in their needs and learn how to share why it is important to them. This helps them to slowly understand they are not entitled to anything.
Appreciations:
Help the narcissistic partner to think about what the other person adds to their life and to acknowledge it.
Accept the things you can't change.
Helpful for both partners to understand there are some things that are unlikely to ever completely be different in their dynamics. Helps partners make a choice about the relationship from that space of acceptance.
Aftermath of a Regrettable Incident:
Introduction to Narcissistic person about their role in feeling disrespected or unappreciated.
Active listening exercises like the Gottman-Rapport


You must interrupt patterns of rage, repeated interruptions, storming off, or screaming.
Be on the lookout for a partner who has NPD to be overly charming or makes big declarations of victimhood, or says their only goal is “to fight for the relationship.”
Avoid becoming a victim of triangulation or becoming caught up in buying into the hope that you can fix the narcissistic behaviors.
You MUST be comfortable being direct, holding a strong position of authority in the room, and be willing to call out poor behavior that is impacting the relationship.
Strongly suggest and sometimes require that both partners be in individual therapy and check in with this therapist to make sure they are aware of the dynamics happening in the relationship.
The only goal you may accomplish is validating the victim that they are correct in their reality and that they can trust their intuition. You may serve as the objective voice this person needs to get clear and end the relationship.
Don’t fight, argue, or try to overpower the narcissist.
There is a very strong likelihood that despite your support that these sessions may not go as you hope!
Many clients who have narcissistic behaviors can and will use the tools they learn in session to abuse, further manipulate, or weaponize against their partner.
True NPD will NOT be ok with the change in or loss of power and will retaliate.
Evaluate if the partner is becoming more agitated, aggressive, and if you suspect there is an increased likelihood for physical abuse-stop sessions.
Recognize you can and potentially should take a break from therapy with the couples.
Should you refer them to seek individual therapy for a while and then re-evaluate if they are good candidates for couples therapy?
Couples therapy can re-traumatize the partner who is being victimized.
Consider if this is in the scope of your practice? Do you need to refer out?


Make time before letting clients go to let them know that it was a hard session and how important it was to have it.
Let your partner know that if they are flooded when they will come back and talk about it with you. Make a date with each other to come back and process.
Check in with each partner about what they will do to self-soothe.
Remind clients that emotions and feeling hurt or misunderstood happens in relationships. The couple is not in this situation because they don’t love each other but because the stakes are so high. This is your person and if we are not ok then nothing feels ok.
Let them know you are proud of them for doing the work.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Training/Strategies for Working with High Conflict Couples.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: ECR-SF Scoring
item.description:
Results consist of two scores for the two separate factors; Attachment anxiety and attachment avoidance. The minimum score for each scale is 7 and a maximum score of 42. In addition, scores are represented in terms of percentile ranks compared to a normative sample. A percentile of 50 represents typical (and healthy) attachment, whereas higher percentiles represent more difficulties with adult attachment compared to peers.
Attachment avoidance is defined as involving fear of dependence and interpersonal intimacy, an excessive need for self-reliance, and reluctance to self-disclose.
Attachment anxiety is defined as involving a fear of interpersonal rejection or abandonment, an excessive need for approval from others, and distress when one’s partner is unavailable or unresponsive.
People who score high on either or both of these dimensions are assumed to have an insecure adult attachment orientation. By contrast, people with low levels of attachment anxiety and avoidance can be viewed as having a secure adult attachment orientation (Brennan et al., 1998). In addition, higher scores are significantly and positively related to depression, anxiety, interpersonal distress, or loneliness.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Preparing for Co-Therapy
item.description:
Before each session co-therapists should have a pre-session meeting. Therapists pre-session so that co-therapists are on the same page. During pre-sessioning you should decide on the following:
The intention or goals for the session
Agreement on a theoretical model
Create a session specific game plan
Discuss previous sessions, hypotheses, and evaluation of progress
Make decisions about next steps in treatment
You should also consider the following questions amongst yourself:
What would blow you out of the water?
What would be so shocking that you wouldn't know what to do?
Let's brainstorm what we would do if XYZ occurred in session
Examples (arguing, escalation, high conflict, desire to end relationship, risk, etc.)
How would you manage that?
What do you anticipate?
What is your theory of what's going on--your theory of the problem?
Strategies for the therapy room
As a co-therapy team you should determine which strategies you are going to use in the room. What is the role of each therapist and how will you work together.
Some strategies to consider:
Tag team
One starts speaking, while the other would be writing questions, and perhaps nodding occasionally, or making validating and summarizing statements.
Then, when number one (i.e. the one who was speaking) runs out number two is ready. They're ready, because they've been writing questions, and they can jump in with those questions.
Preparation and sharing airtime
Who will do what in the session? Who is handling assessment or genogram?
Will we ever spend time one on one or break up subsystems of the client system?
Split the joining tasks
Before you go into the room, you decide which member of the couple each therapist will focus on with joining.
For example:
You're going to join with the husband, and I'm going to join with the wife.
It's very specific who we're each validating, empathizing, and summarizing. If you start asking questions of the husband, it's my job to ask the follow-up questions of the wife. In the same vein with the wife, so that we're like two advocates.
Reflecting Team
As co-therapists there may be times when you find it appropriate to turn to one another and talk about what is going on or what you notice in the room. This could be used as an intervention or to help determine the next steps in the session.
Example:
Co-therapists turn to one another and debate or argue about what is happening with the client system. Have a discussion or debate about what is going on, and then turn back to the couple and say, "Where are we going wrong?, or "How are we getting it right?"
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Questions for Clients
item.description:
Questions for both:
What happened to your marriage that's gotten you to the point where divorce is a possibility?
Can you tell me what you have done to try to fix the problems in the marriage, whether on your own or with help?
What role, if any, do your children play in your decision making about the future of your relationship?
Can you tell me about a time in your relationship, since the time you met, when you felt the most connection and joy?
Questions for Leaning-Out partner (see this person first):
Tell me more about your pain and reasons for considering divorce.
(Within no more than 10 minutes) switch to a conversation about the paths.
Find out how far they have gone in formalizing divorce plans (contacted attorney, papers drawn up, etc.)
Ask them their perspective on their contributions to the problems in the marriage.
Prepare a summary statement for the other partner about something they have taken away from the individual time, then invite partner 2 in the room to hear the summary statement.
Now work with the leaning-in partner:
Help them articulate that they understand their partner's concerns and can understand why their partner might be interested in divorce.
Ask about their perspective on their own contributions to the problems in the relationship.
Help them figure out how to respond without being too anxious or withdrawing completely.
Summary statement:
Must convey the sense that the leaning-in partner understands why their partner is contemplating divorce, and some empathy for this position.
Once both people are in the room again, and the leaning-in partner has shared their summary statement, then the therapist shares their observations.
What themes have you noticed, and your perception of how they got to this place.
Couple does not have to agree on a path at the end of this session, but they may, they recommend that the couple return for at least a 2 nd discernment session before deciding, especially Path 3.


What is happening in your lives that you want to continue to have happen?
What do you think the problem is now?
How will you know when the problem is solved?
How will you know when you don't have to come here anymore? What will the signs be?
What will have to be different about others involved in the situation?
What is your wildest fantasy about what you want to happen?


What would it take to get your family member (or the court) off of your back?


What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that afterward you will look back and be able to say it was a good idea?
What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that this will not have been a waste of your time?
Often in our experience, we have found that in between scheduling an appointment and coming in, something happens that contributes to making a problem better. Has anything happened to improve the problems that brought you here today?


So, what has to happen to get your mother off of your back?
What is the minimum we need to accomplish so that you won't have to keep coming for more sessions?
What would it take to get your family (or court) off of your back?


Between now and next time we meet, I would like you to observe what happens that you want to continue to have happen?


What brings you here today? How can I be helpful to you?
What changes have you noticed since you first made the call to set up this appointment?


When in the past might the problem have happened but it didn't?


How did you do that? How did you get that to happen?


How have you managed to cope, ensure, keep going?


What will it take to move from a 3 to a 4?
On a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being absolutely no hope, and 10 being complete hope, what number would you give your current level of hope?


Therapy begins with a description of the clients' problem.
How were you hoping I could help you?
Asking for clients' perceptions
Acknowledge clients' perceptions, using clients own language as much as possible.
As clients what they've already tried to resolve their difficulties.



It sounds as though [problem] is part of your life now.
How long have you been noticing this [problem]?
What effect does the [problem] have on your life?
How does the [problem] impact your relationship?
Does [problem] have an impact on your relationship with other family members?
What do you think about the effects [problem] is having on your life?
Are you accepting what [problem] is doing?
Are these effects acceptable to you or not?
Why is this? Why are you taking this position on what [problem] is doing?
How would you prefer things to be?


What name would you give the problem?
What is it like to experience the problem?
What effect does the problem have on your life?
What effect does the problem have on your relationship with each other?
What has it talked you into about your family? What impacts has that had?
What effects does the problem have on your other relationships?
How does the problem alter your relationship with yourself?
Is this what you want for your life? Why or why not?
Are we talking about what you want to be talking about?
Is this conversation useful? How is it useful?


Who is in charge, the person or the problem?


Reading between the lines of the problem story
Can you remember a time...


What does it say about you...


If we are not hearing the name, we might ask the family to name them
What would you call that something?
What 'feeds' the problem?
What 'starves' the problem?
Who benefits from the problem?
In what settings might the problem be useful?
Who advocates for the problem?
What groups of people would be opposed to the problem and its intentions?
What are the effects of the problem on members of the family? On their lives and relationships?


Have you ever been able to escape the problem even for a few minutes?
Is the problem always with you?


What was it like to hear what so-and-so was saying?
What thoughts were you having as so-and-so was talking?
It is useful to ask questions that, rather than leaving the field for response wide open, more specifically invite people to respond to unique outcomes and preferred directions
Were you surprised when so-and-so described you as taking the time to let others know you care?
What did it mean to you to hear so-and-so say how important the relationship is to them?


Creating a setting where people can tell their preferred stories to a group of outsiders, who them amplify and accredit the stories that they witness
What stood out for them?
What images it brought forward?
How it resonated with their own experiences?
Where they were transported by the interview?
Situate their reflections in their own experience
Comment on the difference that being part of the conversation makes on their own lives


Opening space questions (unique outcomes)
Has there been a time when arguing could have taken control of your relationship but did not?
Preference questions (preferred experiences)
Was this way of handling things better or worse? And how?
Story development questions
How is this different from when arguing is in control?
Meaning questions
What does it say about you that you were able to...?
Questions that extend the story into the future
What do you predict...

item.title: Relationship Questionnaire
item.description:
How did you and your partner meet? Tell me your story.
What attracted you to your partner?
What are some of the strengths of your relationship?
Currently, what is the most serious threat to your relationship?
When did you first notice problems of a serious nature?
Do you wish to please your partner?
What are the actions you currently do to please your partner?
What are the actions your partner takes to currently please you?
What actions would you like your partner to take to please you?
What attributes do you like about your partner?
What attributes does your partner likes about you?
What behaviors of your partner do you find irritating?
What behaviors of yours does your partner find irritating?
What are some negative attributes of your family origin?
What are some positive attributes of your family origin?
What are some negative attributes of your partner's family origin?
What are some positive attributes of your partner's family origin?

item.title: Acculturation
item.description: The process by which elements of minority and majority cultures blend with each other, but each retains its main identifying markers. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Allegiance Bias
item.description: The tendency for researchers to design studies in such a way that favors their preferred method of therapy.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Antecedent
item.description:
Noun:
A thing or event that existed before or logically precedes another.
Adjective:
Preceding in time or order; previous or preexisting.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Antisocial Behavior
item.description:
Defined as behavior that is harmful to others by breaking important social or moral norms. (pg. 1720)
Antisocial behavior is very costly to society. (pg. 1720)
Many interventions have been designed to reduce antisocial behavior, and especially Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) programs have shown to be relatively effective. (pg. 1720)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Assimilation
item.description: The process of becoming integrated into the surrounding context.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Attachment
item.description: The innate tendency to seek out closeness to caretakers in the face of stress.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Aversion Control
item.description: Using punishment and criticism to eliminate undesirable responses; commonly used in dysfunctional families. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Belmont Report
item.description:
The ethical principles are respect for persons, beneficence, and justice.
Respect for Persons:Respect for Persons



This principle includes two requirements:
Acknowledge and treat individuals as autonomous.
Protect those with limited autonomy.
Beneficence:Beneficence



Two general rules reflect this principle:
Do no harm.
Maximize possible benefits and minimize possible harms.
Justice:Justice



This principle requires researchers to:
Treat people fairly.
Design research to share burdens and benefits equitably.
Balancing the Three Principles:
According to the Belmont Report, "These principles cannot always be applied so as to resolve beyond dispute particular ethical problems. The objective is to provide an analytical framework that will guide the resolution of ethical problems arising from research involving human subjects."
In some cases, the principle present competing claims for resolving ethical problems. (i.e., informing subjects about some aspects of the research would invalidate the research, the principle of respect for persons may be compromised in order to provide benefit)
Federal Regulations for Protecting Research Subjects:
The 'Federal Policy for Protection of Human Subjects' (the Common Rule) includes a list of criteria for the review of research. These criteria reflect the ethical principles outlines in the Belmont Report: respect for persons, beneficence, and justice.
Review Criteria for Expedited and Full Review:
IRB members conducting an expedited review, or a convened IRB conducting a full review, must determine the following:
Risks to subjects are minimized:
By using procedures that are consistent with sound research design and that do not unnecessarily expose subjects to risk.
Whenever appropriate, by using procedures already being performed on the subjects for diagnostic or treatment purposes.
Risks to subjects are reasonable in relation to anticipated benefits, if any, to subjects, and the importance of the knowledge that may be reasonably be expected to result.
In evaluating risks and benefits, the IRB should consider only those risks and benefits that may result from the research (as distinguished from risks and benefits of therapies subjects would receive even if not participating in the research). The IRB should not consider possible long-range effects of applying knowledge gained in the research (e.g., the possible range effects of the research on public policy) as among those research risks that fall within the purview of its responsibility.
Selection of subjects is equitable.
In making this assessment the IRB should take into account the purposes of the research and the setting in which the research will be conducted. The IRB should be particularly cognizant of the special problems of research that involves a category of subjects who are vulnerable to coercion or undue influence (such as, children, prisoners, individuals with impaired decision-making capacity, or economically or educationally disadvantaged persons).
Informed consent will be sought from each prospective subject or the subject's legally authorized representative.
Informed consent will be appropriately documented, or appropriately waived.
When appropriate, the research plan makes adequate provision for monitoring the data collected to ensure the safety of subjects.
When appropriate, there are adequate provisions to protect the privacy of subjects and to maintain the confidentiality of data.
For purposes of conducting the limited IRB review, the IRB shall make the following determinations:
Broad consent for storage, maintenance, and secondary research use of identifiable private information or identifiable biospecimens is obtained.
Broad consent is appropriately documented or waiver of documentation is appropriate.
If there is a change made for research purposes in the way the identifiable private information or identifiable biospecimens are stored or maintained, there are adequate provisions to protect the privacy of subjects and to maintain the confidentiality of data.
When some or all of the subjects are likely to be vulnerable to coercion or under influence (such as, children, prisoners, individuals with impaired decision-making capacity, or economically or educationally disadvantaged persons), additional safeguards must be included in the study to protect the rights and welfare of these subjects.
Federal regulations provide a list of criteria that the IRB must determine are satisfied in order to approve research. The criteria reflect the ethical principles identified in the Belmont Report.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Beneficence
item.description:
Two general rules reflect this principle:
Do no harm.
Maximize possible benefits and minimize possible harms.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Black Box Concept
item.description: The idea that because the mind is so complex, it's better to study people's input and output (behavior, communication) then to speculate about what goes on in their minds.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Blended Families
item.description: Separate families united by marriage; stepfamilies.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Circular Questioning
item.description: A method of interviewing developed by the Milan Associates in which questions are asked that highlight differences among family members. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Client Variables
item.description: Attributes of clients that are thought to contribute to successful outcomes, such as proactivity and motivation.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Closed System
item.description: A functionally related group of elements regarded as forming a collective entity that does not interact with the surrounding environment.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Collaborative Model
item.description: A more egalitarian view of the therapist's role; advocated by critics of what is viewed as authoritarianism in traditional approaches to family therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Common Factors
item.description: The factors surrounding the delivery of therapy as well as common elements of treatment conceptualization and delivery across different therapeutic models. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Comparative Effectiveness Trials
item.description: Randomized controlled trials with high external validity and low internal validity. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Comparative Efficacy Trials
item.description: Randomized controlled trials with high external validity and low internal validity. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Complementary Relationship
item.description:
Based on differences that fit together, where qualities of one make up for lacks in the other; one is one-up, whole the other is one-down. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Based on differences that fit together, where qualities of one make up for lacks in the other; one is one-up, while the other is one-down. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019, Chapter 1)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Construal Humility
item.description:
Partners in a couple, seeing the same moment in different ways, may engage in “dueling realities.”
Making room for multiple narratives and differences of perspective and opinion, and recognizing the right of each to their own experience, are key aspects of relational ethics. Mentalization is the awareness that others have their own ways of thinking and experiencing.
The therapist offers “construal humility” as a model, noting that we all construe or make sense of our world, but there are multiple ways to look at most interactions. Making room for dual narratives rather than dueling narratives is a key skill of relational ethics in both couple and intergenerational relationships.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Constructivism
item.description: A relativistic point of view that emphasizes the subjective construction of reality. Implies that what we see in families may be based as much on our preconceptions as on what's actually going on. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Content
item.description:
What families talk about. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019, Chapter 1)
The circumstances or phenomena out of the context of those actions or changes (Process) (@kerrFamilyEvaluation1988)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Countertransference
item.description: Emotional reactivity on the part of the therapist. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cross-Generational Coalition
item.description: An inappropriate alliance between a parent and child, who side together against a third member of the family. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cybernetics
item.description:
The science of feedback; how information, especially positive and negative feedback loops, can help self-regulate a system. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Introduced by Gregory Bateson
The study of feedback mechanisms in self-regulating systems
Feedback Loop:
How a system gets information necessary to maintain a steady state.
Can be positive or negative.
Negative Feedback:
Indicates that a system is straying off the mark and that corrections are needed to get back on track.
Room Temperature->Thermostat->Furnace->Room Temperature
Positive Feedback:
Reinforces the direction a system is taking.
Being out of Breath-> Overcorrecting-> Escalation of Panic attack->Being out of Breath
If you see behavior persist over time, there is likely something maintaining that behavior.
Cybernetics in Families:
Sequences of family interaction around a problem; characterize system's reaction to it.
What happens when the system's negative feedback is ineffective?
Triggering positive feedback loops.
Implications for MFTs:
Oriented-Therapists strive for:
Second-Order Change
Distinguishing it from first-order change
Change in family rules
First-Order Change:
Family changes behavior, but is still governed by the same rules.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Demand-Withdraw (Pursuer-Distancer)
item.description: A 'female-demand/male-withdraw' pattern or a 'female-pursuer/male-distancer' pattern is dysfunctional. This one is true. Andy Christensen has pioneered the research in this area of couple relationships.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Detriangulation
item.description: The process by which individuals remove themselves from the emotional field of two others. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Directives
item.description: Homework assignments designed to help families interrupt homeostatic patterns of problem-maintaining behavior. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Disclosure
item.description:
Disclosure with peers and supervisors helps to accept struggles.
Influenced by trust in the therapist and believing self-disclosure would be beneficial.
Promotes healing and attachment, but decision should be left to offending spouse.
Disclosure is the best course of action to resolve potential conflicts and improve working alliance.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Double Bind
item.description:
A conflict created when an individual receives contradictory messages on different levels of abstraction in an important relationship and cannot leave or comment. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Gregory Bateson
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Dyadic Model
item.description: Explanations based on the interactions between two individuals or objects; Johnny shoplifts to get his mother's attention. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Empirically Validated Treatment
item.description: A treatment for which a substantial amount of research exists supporting its effectiveness. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Entitlement
item.description: Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy's term for the amount of merit a person accrues for behaving in an ethical manner toward others. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Epistemology
item.description:
The branch of philosophy concerned with the study of knowledge. Used by Gregory Bateson to mean worldview or belief system. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Way of knowing
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Equifinality
item.description: The ability of complex systems to reach a given final goal in a variety of different ways. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Equipping Youth to Help One Another (EQUIP)
item.description:
Effective in neutralizing decreases in social skills and moral value evaluations. (pg. 1720)
Earlier studies yield contrasting results on the effectiveness of EQUIP. (pg. 1720)
Not effective in reducing cognitive distortions and improving moral judgement. (pg. 1720)
Aims to teach antisocial youth to think and act responsibly. (pg. 1720)
EQUIP is implemented in all juvenile correctional facilities as part of a nationwide methodology. (pg. 1720)
EQUIP is designed to teach antisocial youth to think and act responsibly by combining a peer helping and skills-streaming approach. The peer helping approach of the EQUIP program is based on the Positive Peer Culture (PPC)
This is a positive culture in which individuals feel responsible for each other and actually help one another. (pg. 1721)
A peer helping approach alone is not sufficient to counter negative peer pressure, since antisocial youth often lack the skills necessary to adequately help each other. (pg. 1721)

The EQUIP program therefore also targets three specific 'limitations' of antisocial youth:
Cognitive Distortions:
Described as 'inaccurate or rationalizing attitudes, thoughts, or beliefs concerning own or other's behavior.'
Social Skill Deficiencies:
Described as 'imbalanced and unconstructive behavior in difficult interpersonal situation.'
Moral Developmental Delays:
Described as "the persistence beyond early childhood of an immature moral judgement and a pronounced 'me-centeredness' or 'egocentric bias.'"
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Equipping Youth to Help One Another (EQUIP).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Essentialist Approach
item.description:
@holleyExploringBasisGender2010
Popular stereotypical conceptions of Martian men and Venetian women (e.g., Gray, 1993)
Suggest the differences between men and women stem from innate biological or psychological attributes.
Previous studies have suggested men are less able to tolerate sustained levels of physiological arousal than women. This also suggest men and women grow up in differing social worlds. (Holley et al., (2010))
(Smith et al., (2010)) Stable differences between men and women explain why wife-demand/husband-withdraw (WDHW) occurs more than husband-demand/wife-withdraw (HDWW) (Eldridge & Christensen, 2002). Some scholars have proposed that women are socialized to be more oriented towards relationships than are men (Napier, 1978)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ethnicity
item.description: The common ancestry through which groups of people have evolved shared values and customs. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Exception
item.description:
De Shazer's term for times when clients are temporarily free of their problems. Solution-focused therapists focus on exceptions to help clients build on successful problem-solving skills. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Steve de Shazer
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Exposure
item.description: Describes the length and frequency of the sessions implemented by the facility. (@helmondProgramIntegrityEffectiveness2012)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Extended Family
item.description: The network of kin relationships across several generations. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: External Validity
item.description: The degree to which the results of a study are generalizable to populations outside a study; achieved by allowing the study conditions to approximate standard practice as much as possible. Studies with high external validity typically have low internal validity due to the lack of control present in treatment delivery and clinical sample. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Externalization
item.description:
Michael White's technique of personifying problems as external to individuals. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Social Constructionism
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Extinction
item.description: Eliminating behavior by not reinforcing it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Extratherapeutic Factors
item.description: Factors in a client's life that are outside of the scope of therapy but have a strong bearing on the client's life, such as jobs, neighborhood, or family composition. Changes in extratherapeutic factors have been hypothesized to account for more change than what occurs in therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR)
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Families
item.description: Groups of related people, bound by connections that are biological, legal, or emotional. (@cohenFamilyDiversityInequality2018)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Drawing
item.description: An experiential therapy technique in which family members are asked to draw their ideas about how the family is organized. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Group Therapy
item.description: Family treatment based on the group therapy model. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Homeostasis
item.description: Tendency of families to resist change in order to maintain a steady state. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Life Cycle
item.description: Stages of family life from separation from parents to marriage, having child, growing older, retirement, and finally death. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Myths
item.description: A set of beliefs based on a distortion of historical reality and shared by all family members that help shape the rules governing family functioning. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family of Origin
item.description: An individual's parents and siblings; usually refers to the original nuclear family of an adult. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Projection Process
item.description: In Bowenian theory, the mechanism by which parental conflicts are projected onto the children or a spouse. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Ritual
item.description: Technique used by Selvini Palazzoli and her Milan associates that prescribes a specific act for family members to perform, which is designed to change the family system's rules. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family System
item.description: The family conceives as a collective whole entity made up of individual parts plus the way they function together. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: First-Generation Students
item.description:
First generation students may find it more difficult to ask for help.
They may worry they are seen as difficult or demanding.
They deserve success just as much as their privileged counterparts.
They find that graduate school feels like getting locked out when everyone else has the key.
They face criticism from family and friends about the demands of graduate school or the type of person they have become.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: First-Order Cybernetics (1940s-1960s)
item.description: The idea that an outside observer can study and make changes in a system while remaining separate and independent of that system. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Fixation
item.description: Partial arrest of attachment or mode of behavior from an early stage of development. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Formula First-Session Task
item.description:
Solution-Focused Therapy
Solution-Focused therapists routinely ask clients at the end of the first session to think about what they do not want to change as a result of therapy. This focuses them on strengths in their lives and begins the solution-generating process.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Function of the System
item.description: The idea that the symptoms are often ways to distract or otherwise protect family members from threatening conflicts. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Genealogy
item.description: The study of ancestry and family history. (@cohenFamilyDiversityInequality2018)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Generalizability
item.description: In learning theory terms, spreading effect. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Genogram
item.description:
A schematic diagram of the family system, using squares to represent men, circles to indicate women, horizontal lines for marriages, and vertical lines to indicate children. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
A multigenerational family tree that symbolically represents different dynamics related to family and individual functioning that is psychologic, cultural, and interpersonal in nature. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024)
“Genogram Symbols.pdf” could not be found.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Group Dynamics
item.description: Interactions among group members that emerge as a result of properties of the group rather than merely their individual personalities. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH)
item.description:
Increases patient rights over their PHI
Increases restrictions over disclosure of PHI
Increased fines for HIPAA violations
Funding for compliance audits
Compliance:
If you furnish bills, receive payments for health care, and any transactions are sent in electronic form, you are a covered entity (CE).
If an organization creates, receives, maintains, or transmits PHI on behalf of a CE, it is considered a business association of the CE.
If you take self-pay only and do not bill insurance, then you might not be a CE, but HIPAA is becoming a standard of care.
State Laws and our Ethics Code are actually more stringent than HIPAA around the confidentiality and privacy of therapy in terms of notes, diagnoses, etc.
When working for a CE, have to provide a Notice of Privacy Practices, a disclosure about what information can be shared and what can’t be.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA)
item.description:
Makes health information portable so that individuals can maintain health insurance between jobs.
Ensure that health care plans and providers are held accountable with regard to keeping health information private
Provides federal privacy protections for physical and mental health information known as protected health information (PHI).
Compliance:
If you furnish bills, receive payments for health care, and any transactions are sent in electronic form, you are a covered entity (CE).
If an organization creates, receives, maintains, or transmits PHI on behalf of a CE, it is considered a business association of the CE.
If you take self-pay only and do not bill insurance, then you might not be a CE, but HIPAA is becoming a standard of care.
State Laws and our Ethics Code are actually more stringent than HIPAA around the confidentiality and privacy of therapy in terms of notes, diagnoses, etc.
When working for a CE, have to provide a Notice of Privacy Practices, a disclosure about what information can be shared and what can’t be.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Hope and Expectancy Factors
item.description: The hope a therapist and client have in the successful outcome of therapy; thought to increase the chances of successful therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Idealization
item.description: A tendency to exaggerate the virtues of someone, part of the normal developmental process in children's relationships to their parents and in intimate partnerships. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identification
item.description: From psychoanalytic theory, not merely imitation but appropriation of traits of an admired other. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identified Patient (IP)
item.description: The symptom-bearer or official patient as identified by the family. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Instrumental Leader
item.description: Decision-making and task functions; in traditional families, the husband's role. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internal Family Systems Model
item.description: A model of the mind that uses systemic principles and techniques understand and change intrapsychic processes, developed by Richard Schwartz. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internal Objects
item.description: Mental images and fantasies of oneself and others, formed by early interactions with caregivers. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internal Validity
item.description: The degree to which a study measures what it claims to measure. Internal validity is achieved by controlling the effects of as many variable that might affect the outcome of the study as possible. Studies with high internal validity tend to have low external validity since nobody delivers services in such a tightly controlled manner to such carefully screened clients. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Introjection
item.description: A primitive form of identification; taking in aspects of other individuals, which then become part of the self-image. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Invariant Prescription
item.description: A technique developed by Mara Selvini Palazzoli in which parents are directed to mysteriously sneak away together. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Invisible Loyalties
item.description: Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy's term for unconscious and commitments that children take on to help their families. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Justice
item.description:
This principle requires researchers to:
Treat people fairly.
Design research to share burdens and benefits equitably.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Linear Causality
item.description: The idea that one event is the cause and another is the effect; in behavior, the idea that one behavior is a stimulus, the other a response. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Managed Care
item.description: A system in which third-party companies manage insurance costs by regulating the terms of treatment. Managed care companies select providers, set fees, and control who receives treatment and how many sessions they are entitled to. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Marital Schism
item.description:
Lidz's term for pathological overt marital conflict. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Marital Skew
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Marital Skew
item.description:
Lidz's term for a pathological marriage in which one spouse dominates the other. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Marital Schism
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Maternal Overprotectiveness
item.description:
David Levy (1943)

Levy believed maternal overprotectiveness stems from mothers who were deprived of love, and it developed into either domineering or overindulgent behaviors.
Believed it was the cause of child's problems.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mental Disorder
item.description:
A mental disorder syndrome characterized by clinically significant disturbance in an individual's cognition, emotional regulation, or behavior that reflects a dysfunction in the psychological, biological, or developmental processes underlying mental functioning.
Mental disorders are usually associated with significant distress or disability in social, occupational, or other important activities. An expectable or culturally approved response to a common stressor or loss, such as death of a loved one, is not a mental disorder.
Socially deviant behavior (i.e., political, religious, or sexual) and conflicts that are primarily between the individual and society are not mental disorders unless the deviance or conflict results from a dysfunction in the individual, as described above.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mental Research Institute (MRI)
item.description:
Mental Research Institute
The MRI Pioneers:
Don Jackson
Gregory Bateson (As a consultant)
Virginia Satir
John Weakland
Jay Haley
Paul Watzlawick
Richard Fisch
Jules Riskin
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Meta-Analysis
item.description: A research methodology that quantitatively aggregates the findings of multiple studies focused on a common phenomenon. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Metacommunication
item.description:
Every message has two levels: report and command; metacommunication is the implied command or qualifying message. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Gregory Bateson
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mirroring
item.description: Expression of understanding and acceptance of another's feelings. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Modeling
item.description: Observational Learning (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Morphogenesis
item.description:
The process by which a system changes its structure to adapt to new contexts. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to change in order to accommodate to the new information.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Morphostasis
item.description: As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to maintain itself in the same way, however because of the new information it has to change in some way to stay the same (assimilation).
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Multidirected Partiality
item.description:
A balanced therapeutic alliance is crucial for the success of couple therapy; the therapist does not accept the role of judge. If there is egregious or abusive behavior, the therapist takes a stand; violence is out of bounds and the principle of safety first is bedrock in any therapy.
Nevertheless, even setting limits and identifying problematic behavior is done from a place of concern and compassion. The therapist maintains a stance of “multidirected partiality” partial to each partner, on each one’s side. When clients feel understood and affirmed, the therapist can challenge them. Multidirected partiality is not neutrality; the therapist cares about both partners, is partial to each. But the partiality is balanced.
The couple therapy office must be a “shame-free, blame-free zone,” a safe environment for clients to explore their vulnerabilities and relational disappointments.
It is crucial that clinicians be aware of their own vulnerabilities and survival strategies, and note when they get caught up in a vulnerability cycle with clients. Therapists need to address unfinished business with their own family of origin.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mystery Questions
item.description: Questions designed to get clients wondering how their problems got the best of them, which helps to externalize the problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mystification
item.description: Laing's concept that many families distort their children's experience by denying it or relabeling it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Narcissism
item.description: Self-regard. Exaggerated self-regard most people equate with narcissisms is pathological narcissism. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Negative Feedback
item.description:
Information that signals a system to correct a deviation and restore the status quo. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Feedback Loop
Cybernetics
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Neutrality
item.description: Selvini Palazzoli's term for balanced acceptance of family members. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Nonmaleficence
item.description: "Let us first do no harm."
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Nuclear Family
item.description: Parents and their children. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Object Relations
item.description:
Internalized images of self and others based on early parent-child interactions that determine an individual's mode of relationship to other people. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/People in CFT/Henry Dicks
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Object Relations Theory
item.description: Psychoanalytic theory derived from Melanie Klein and developed by the British School (Bion, Fairbairn, Guntrip, Winnicott) that emphasizes relationships and attachment, rather than libidinal and aggressive drives, as the key issues of human concern. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Open System
item.description: A set of interrelated elements that exchange information, energy, and material with the surrounding environment. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ordeals
item.description: A type of paradoxical intervention in which the client is directed to do something that is more of a hardship than the symptom. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Overgeneralization
item.description:
Isolated incidents are taken as general patterns.
Example:
After being turned down for a date, a young man decides that 'Women don't like me; I'll never get a date.'
Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019
Cognitive Distortions
Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Palo Alto (1952)
item.description: Gregory Bateson
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Paradox
item.description: A self-contradictory statement based on a valid deduction from acceptable premises. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Paradoxical Injunction
item.description:
A technique used in Strategic Family Therapy whereby the therapist directs family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain; if they rebel, they give up their symptoms. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Not to point out that an individual is fighting going under, but instead tell the individual to keep their eyes open until they become unbearably heavy.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Parental Child
item.description: A child who has been allocated power to take care of younger siblings; adaptive when done deliberately in large or single-parent families, maladaptive when it results from unplanned abdication of parental responsibility. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Personal Family
item.description: The people to whom we feel related and who we expect to define us as members of their family as well. (@cohenFamilyDiversityInequality2018)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Positive Connotation
item.description: Selvini Palazzoli's technique of ascribing positive motives to family behavior in order to promote family cohesion and avoid resistance to therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Positive Feedback
item.description:
Information that confirms and reinforces the direction a system is taking. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Feedback Loop
Cybernetics
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Postmodernism
item.description:
Contemporary antipositivism, viewing knowledge as relative and context-dependent; questions assumptions of objectivity that characterize modern science. In family therapy, challenging the idea of scientific certainty and linked to the method of deconstruction. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Narrative Therapy
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Preferred View
item.description: Eron and Lund's term for the way people would like to think of themselves and be seen by others. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Premature Termination (PT)
item.description:
@andersonTherapeuticAllianceCultural2019

PT is a pervasive barrier that effects outpatient outcomes.
It is poorly understood from the client perspective.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Prescribing the Symptom
item.description: A paradoxical technique that forces a patient to either give up a symptom or admit that it is under voluntary control. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Pretend Techniques
item.description: Madanes's playful paradoxical intervention in which family members are asked to pretend to engage in symptomatic behavior. The paradox is if they are pretending to have a symptom, the symptom cannot be real. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Process
item.description:
How members of a family or group relate. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
A continuous series of actions or changes that rsult in a given set of circumstances or phenomena. (@kerrFamilyEvaluation1988)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Process Research
item.description: Quantitative or qualitative research that systematically observes treatment delivery to determine processes indicative of successful therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Program Drift
item.description: The aims and objectives of treatment change over time. (@helmondProgramIntegrityEffectiveness2012)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Program Integrity
item.description:
The extent to which an intervention is implemented as intended. (pg. 1720)
Provides insight into why programs work or do not work. (pg. 1720)
There is a major caveat in previous effectiveness research with the absence of information on program integrity. It is often unknown to what extent programs are actually implemented as originally intended (i.e., program integrity). (pg. 1720)
The absence of significant intervention effects can be explained either as a lack of effectiveness of the intervention itself, or as a failure to implement the intervention as originally intended. (pg. 1720)
Based on the limited information on program integrity provided, there are differences with program implementation and integrity across studies. (pg. 1721)
Without documentation of program integrity it is impossible to determine whether significant, non-significant or ambiguous findings can be attributed to the theoretical model underly- ing the program, or to the implementation of the program. (pg. 1721)


Program Drift:
The aims and objectives of treatment change over time.
Program Reversal:
The goals of treatment are undermined or threatened.
Program Non-Compliance:
The content of the program is altered, or goals are changed or abandoned without reference to theoretical or empirical evidence.


Exposure:
Describes the length and frequency of the sessions implemented by the facility
Adherence:
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Program Reversal
item.description: The goals of treatment are undermined or threatened. (@helmondProgramIntegrityEffectiveness2012)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Projective Identification
item.description: A defense mechanism that operates unconsciously, whereby unwanted aspects of the self are attributed to another individual, and that individual is induced to behave in accordance with these projected attitudes and feelings. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Pseudohostility
item.description:
Wynne's term for superficial bickering that masks pathological alignments in schizophrenic families. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Lyman Wynne (1954) 1
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Pseudomutuality
item.description: Lyman Wynne (1954) 1's term for the façade of family harmony that characterizes many schizophrenic families. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Psychoeducational Family Therapy
item.description: A type of therapy developed in work with schizophrenics, which emphasizes educating family members to help them understand and cope with a seriously disturbed family member. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Quid Pro Quo
item.description:
Literally, 'something for something,' an equal exchange or substitution. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Lederer & Jackson proposed The Quid Pro Quo contract as an implicit contract that every relationship contains. It is a contract in which people exchange positive things with one another.
They suggested this kind of reciprocity breaks down in relationships that are ailing, and trust becomes eroded.
In 1977 Bernard Murstein found that quid-pro-quo way of thinking was characteristic of both ailing friendships and relationships.
Once a partner becomes an emotional 'accountant' there is something wrong. (i.e., when the thinking is, "I did this for that person and it never got reciprocated,"), then that is a sign that the relationship is in trouble.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Randomized Controlled Trial
item.description: A research design in which carefully screened participants are randomly assigned to one of two or more bona-fide treatments or a control group, treatments are administered in a carefully controlled manner, and results are compared to determine the most effective treatment. Commonly used in medicine and historically in mental health research, although its popularity in the latter is fading. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Redundancy Principle
item.description: Fact that a family interacts within a limited range of repetitive behavioral sequences.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Reflecting Team
item.description: Tom Anderson's technique of having the observing team share their reactions with the family following a session. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Reframing
item.description: Relabeling a family's description of behavior to make it more amenable to therapeutic change; for example, describing someone as 'lazy' rather than 'depressed.' (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Regression
item.description: Return to a less-mature level of functioning in the face of stress. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Resistance
item.description: Anything that patients or families do to oppose or retard the progress of therapy. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Respect for Persons
item.description:
This principle includes two requirements:
Acknowledge and treat individuals as autonomous.
Protect those with limited autonomy.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Restraining
item.description: A Strategic Family Therapy technique for overcoming Resistance by suggesting that a family not change. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Risk Assessment
item.description:
Risk Assessment includes consideration of psychological and social factors as part of a comprehensive review to capture client needs, and to assess their risk of harm to themselves or others.
Assessments often aim to categorize patients as at high, medium or low risk.
Examples of risk areas include:
Suicidal Ideation
Homicidal Ideation
Child Abuse/Neglect
Intimate Partner Violence
Physical Health Issues or Crises
Inability to care for self or others
Animal Abuse
Substance Use
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Rituals
item.description: In Strategic Family Therapy, a set of prescribed actions designed to change a family system's rules. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Role Reciprocity
item.description: Theodore Lidz

Concentrated on communication
Focusing exclusively on this one aspect of family life neglected individual intersubjectivity as well as broader social influences.

item.description: A member of the family, usually the Identified Patient (IP), who is the object of displaced conflict or criticism. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Second-Order Cybernetics (1960s-1980s)
item.description: The idea that anyone attempting to observe and change a system is therefore part of that system. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Secrets in CFT
item.description:
Responsible handing of secrets is necessary to avoid ethical, legal, and therapeutic problems.
Secrets indirectly influence the couple system due to the consequences and symptoms of secrets.
Literature on the disclosure of secrets in therapy is scarce.
It is unethical for therapists to collude in keeping secrets.
Through voluntary facilitated disclosure or referral therapists should avoid a double-bind while doing therapy with non-disclosed secrets.
@butlerFacilitatedDisclosureClinical2009
