item.title: Stages of Therapist Development
item.description:
@pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018

Therapists trained in individual therapy generally go through three stages of development when learning to do family therapy. In the first stage, they focus on acquiring the skills necessary to work with families. In the second stage, they learn to apply systemic theory to their clinical work, and in the third, “self of the therapist” stage, they focus on more personal issues in relationship to their clinical work
The initial skills stage is characterized by the therapist trying to figure out what to do with clients. This focus then shifts in the theory stage to how to think. In the final stage, the therapist focuses on the use of self in being with a family.


Beginning therapists report feeling overwhelmed by the experience. Many report going home after seeing clients and crying, while others report that the stress results in headaches, difficulty sleeping, stomachaches, or changes in appetite.
Learning to relax and be present in the therapy room with clients is a good place to start. A solid assessment and effective treatment hinge on the therapist’s ability to listen and attend to the client’s story, and to show the client that he or she is understood. Beginners can learn to replace their anxiety about “doing something” with relaxed curiosity and empathy. This approach leads to useful questions and inquiries, which is where therapy begins.


The therapeutic relationship is a necessary but not always sufficient ingredient for change.
To be effective, interventions must be rooted in a clear understanding of family dynamics.
“I know I should be focusing on the process, but I feel like I’m stuck in the content.”
Beginning therapists are able to develop good insights and hypotheses, but will have difficulty connecting these pieces together into a coherent picture or treatment plan
Many therapists find it helpful to adopt a particular theoretical orientation for conceptualizing cases


Explore how the therapist-as-self is both an asset and a liability in therapy. Many of our personal experiences can become catalysts for new ideas and understanding in therapeutic work
Therapists’ unresolved issues or “growth areas” can become impediments in therapy.
The growth and insight derived from working on these issues can provide the perspective necessary to make constructive use of life experiences in therapy.


Thinking (or even obsessing) about clients is something that tends to subside with time and experience.
One reason for this change is that the therapist gradually gains a greater sense of clinical mastery by virtue of experience.
Therapists learn to balance objectivity and emotional involvement with clients. Therapists learn how to construct an emotional boundary


The potential for burnout among beginning therapists exists because of several factors.
Learning to do therapy can be demanding.
Therapists have other stressors outside of their clinical work
The courses or clinical work may raise personal issues for you as you learn to do therapy.
To avoid burnout, practicing good self-care is essential
Taking time for yourself seems counterintuitive when faced with an overwhelming number of tasks to accomplish, but the time lost is often made up by being able to work with renewed energy and efficiency. (many therapists are willing to give this advice to their clients but have difficulty following it themselves.)
Be willing to set limits. As therapists gain experience, they often will become more willing to set some limits on their availability, giving them some protected time for themselves.
You also need a strong social support network
Being with family and friends outside the field will allow you to temporarily escape the demands of being a beginning therapist.
Connecting and obtaining support from your peers within your program is invaluable


Keep the “big picture” in mind and recall the benefits of being a therapist.
Keep the following ‘reminders’ at hand:**
Becoming a therapist takes time. This is an opportunity for you to be a learner; you are not expected to be an expert. Becoming an effective therapist takes several years of training.
Make sure you take care of yourself. Use constructive means for stress reduction. Develop resources for support from other students, peers, and colleagues.
Self-doubts are normal. Be patient with yourself, focus on the positive, and pay attention to the developmental tasks of becoming a therapist.
Use the skills that brought you to the field. While you are learning lots of new theory and material, continue to pay attention to your intuition, your desire to work with others, and your natural abilities.

item.title: System
item.description: A group of interrelated elements plus the way they function together. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: The Cycle of Change
item.description:
Adapted from work by Prochaska and DiClemente (1983)
- Precontemplation:
- A logical starting point for the model, where there is no intention of changing behavior; the person may be unaware that a problem exists
- Contemplation:
- The person becomes aware that there is a problem, but has made no commitment to change.
- Preparation:
- The person is intent on taking action to correct the problem; usually required buy-in from the client (i.e., the client is convinced that the change is good) and increased self-efficacy (i.e., the client believes they can make a change)
- Action:
- The person is in active modification of behavior.
- Maintenance:
- Sustained change occurs and new behavior(s) replaces old ones. Per this model, this stage is also transitional.
- Relapse:
- The person falls back into old patterns of behavior.
- Upward Spiral:
- Each time a person goes through the cycle, they learn from each relapse and (hopefully) grow stronger so that relapse is shorter or less devastating
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Therapeutic Alliance
item.description: The relationship between the therapist and clients. The therapeutic alliance is thought to consist of tasks, bonds, and goals. It is the common factor that enjoys the most empirical support. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Therapist Variables
item.description: Attributes of the therapist that are thought to contribute to successful outcomes, such as the ability to flexibly adapt their approach to the needs of the clients. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Three-Generational Hypothesis of Schizophrenia
item.description: Bowen's concept that schizophrenia is the end result of low levels of differentiation passed on and amplified across three succeeding generations. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Transference
item.description: Distorted emotional reactions to present relationships based on unresolved, early family relations. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Trepanning
item.description:
"A technique used in antiquity where holes were drilled into the skull to allow demonic spirits to escape. The popular view in ancient cultures is that madness was caused by evil spirits who had invaded the body." (Cummings, 2023, pg. 2)
"There are sources that date back roughly 7,000 years ago that show evidence of trepanning." (Cummings, 2023, pg. 2)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Triadic Model
item.description: Explanations based on the interactions among three people or objects; Johnny shoplifts because his father covertly encourages him to defy his mother. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Unconscious
item.description: Memories, feelings, and impulses of which an individual is unaware. Often used as a noun, but more appropriately limited to use as an adjective. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Discernment Counseling
item.description:
Discernment counseling is a short-term process (one to five sessions) with the goal of greater clarity and confidence in the decision about a direction for the marriage, based on a deeper understanding of what has happened to the marriage and each partner's contribution to the problems.
It is not intended for cases in which one partner has made a final decision to divorce and simply wants a venue to convince their spouse to accept the decision.
The immediate decision is whether to carve out a 6-month period of all-out effort in couples therapy to restore the marriage to health, with divorce off the table during that time. At the end of 6 months, they can reopen the decision about divorce on the basis of what they have learned about the prospect of successfully rebuilding their marriage.
Therapy aims for improvement in the relationship (e.g., increased intimacy, decreased toxic conflict), whereas discernment counseling aims for clarity and confidence about a next step. The goal of discernment counseling is not to solve marriage problems but to see whether they can be solved.
There is no relationship homework for couples in discernment counseling, no teaching of skills during sessions, and no enactments of deeper ways to connect.
If clients ask for ways to manage their problems during discernment counseling, we use a 'restraint from change' approach by reminding them that relationship change should not be expected during discernment counseling.
Path 1:
The marraige as it has been: the status quo, neither divorce nor working in therapy to improve the relationship.
Path 2:
Separation or divorce
Path 3:
A 6-month commitment to couples therapy (and sometimes other forms of help, such as substance abuse counseling, parenting classes, or individual therapy) with divorce off the table and with the possibility of putting divorce back on the table at the end of the 6 months.
The idea behind path 3 is to move beyond amibalence about working on change and see whether it is possible to put the marriage into a place that would be good for both partners.
Path 3, as we emphasize repeatedly, involves each partner developing a personal agenda for change on the basis of a deeper understanding of what has happened to the marriage and their role in the problems.
An advantage of framing the immediate outcomes as paths is that it moves clients past the dichotomous choice between staying together or breaking-up.
The therapist too can support the idea that something has to change - the marriage cannot continue as it has been. So sometimes the discernment process begins with agreements instead of disagreement - something has to change; the old ways of being married is no longer viable.
Implicitly we are saying that divorce is not a failure in this process; it is simply one of the options to be explored in a serious way, even thought only one spouse is actively considering it.
Sometimes it has taken years to build up the courage to put divorce on the table in a chronically distressed marriage. Path 3 avoids the 'in or out' conundrum by offering a provisional commitment to work hard on the relationship for a period, with divorce not an option for this period but something that can be revisited later if things do not change enough.
Most of the work occurs in separate conversations with each spouse, with carefully orchestrated sharing of take-home messages from the individual conversations.
The flow of the sessions goes this way:
Time with the couple together
Meeting with one spouse alone (the other goes to the waiting room)
The other spouse returns and the first spouse summarizes key learning from the individual conversation
Meeting with the second spouse alone
The second spouse shares learning from that conversation
A check out with both spouses during which time the therapist shares reflections on the process thus far.
The majority of the time is with each partner alone.
Times when both parties are together in the room are carfully orchestrated to minimize demoralizing exchanges and to maximize the focus on what each is learning about themselves in the process, rather than what each wants the other to change.
The individual conversations have both similar and different areas of focus for the leaning-in and leaning-out partners. Similar themes are helping each better understand the dynamics of the relationship (their relational dance), their individual contributions to the problems, and how these relational and personal issues could be addressed in couples therapy (and sometimes with other helping resources). In terms of different themes, the therapist helps the leaning-out spouse figure out which path to take on the basis of an exploration of the sources of the person’s pain and discouragement about the prospect of change. The focus is on making a decision that has integrity for one’s self and others on the basis of a deeper understanding of self and the marriage and how the problems could be addressed in couples therapy if that is the chosen direction.
The limit of five sessions, although not immutable, creates an expectation of intense work within a limited time frame.
Going on much longer also makes it difficult for the couple not to expect relationship change and for the therapist to not lapse into doing couple interventions.
We say one to five sessions and not five sessions because clients are asked each time about whether they want to do an additional session up to five.
Some people are emotionally flat when their spouse is in the room and then liven up when our one-to-one time begins.


A big part of this approach is helping clients see the difference between traditional marital therapy and discernment counseling and allowing them to indicate their willingness to engage in the process.
We are interested in knowing exactly what the couple knows about discernment counseling.
The clients must leave the conversation with an understanding that the goal for discernment counseling is to help them gain greater clarity and confidence in their decision making about the future of their marriage.


We pay specific attention to whether they are currently living together and the status of any legal proceedings associated with divorce.
After collecting some basic information over the phone, we typically ask something such as, "Can you tell me a bit about your current situation and how do you think it might be helpful to your situation?"


It is important that leaning-out partners feel heard and that they understand how this process is different from anything they have tried as a couple before. It is important to assess whether leaning-out partners have made a decision to divorce or are open to the work of discernment. The following questions can be helpful in determining this:
"Would you say that you've made your decision about the future of your marriage or are you still seeking some level of clarity in this process?"
If they report that they have made a decision, you can ask about their level of confidence in the decision: "How confident are you that you're making the right decision?"
For leaning-out partners who indicate they know they want a divorce and would like to use the session to 'break the news' to their partner, or for those who say they do not know how to tell their partner, you can inform them that this is not consistent with the goals of discernment counseling. You might respond in the following manner:
"It may be that discernment counseling is not exactly a good fit for what you want to do. The goals of discernment counseling are to help people get a greater sense of clarity and confidence in their decision making about a direction for the future of their marriage based on a better understanding of what happened to the marriage to get it to the brink of divorce and each person's role in that. If you're hoping for a different outcome, like helping your spouse understand why you want a divorce, discernment counseling is not appropriate for your situation."


Usually, the leaning-in partner makes it clear that they want to preserve the marriage, but if not, ask that question directly.
If the leaning-in partner feels desperate to do anything to save their marriage, suggest that they purchase and begin reading Michele Weiner-Davis's (2002) book The Divorce Remedy. (They learn that they must first look at themselves and their own behavior before the marriage can get to a healthier place)
"Her book is written specifically for people who have recently found out that their spouse is considering divorce. She gives some practical advice on how you can act toward your partner at this stage of the process. There are probably things you can be working on that will make the situation somewhat better without making your partner feel as though he or she is committing to working on the relationship. This approach may be your best option at the moment."
We cannot emphasize enough the value of respecting client autonomy during this process. Never assume that both parties are equally interested in attending discernment counseling.
Discernment counseling is a way of meeting both parties where they are and not privileging one person's agenda over the other.
"It is really important that your spouse feel as though they have a choice in whether to come to discernment counseling. If he or she feels forced into it, it won't go well and will likely contribute to more estrangement from you on their part. "
Never assume that because one spouse has told you about something that has been happening in the relationship, the other spouse knows about it.


The intake conversation must be conducted one on one, without the person's partner or anyone else in the room. The person on the intake phone call has to be able to speak freely about their perspective on the problems they are having and the struggles they are experiencing making a decision regarding the future of their marriage.
"Are you in a place that you can speak freely without interruptions?"
If there is noise or other distractions, you may want to suggest a different time or place for the call. You also should ascertain whether the client has told their spouse about discernment counseling.
"Have you discussed discernment counseling with your spouse? What do you think is his or her level of interest in participating? Does your spouse know that you and I are speaking today?"
Avoid the temptation to speak to one partner right after the other for the sake of convenience. It is probably worth taking the time at the phone intake to ensure that no one is feeling forced into having this conversation.
There is also benefit to suggesting that the first partner you speak with explain to their partner that they have spoken with a discernment counselor and that if the spouse is interested, they can e-mail or phone the counselor to set up an interview.
In no case should you cold call the other partner, who may not be aware of the initial contact from the spouse.
Consider using the following script as a guide to the initiator of the phone call:
"It sounds like discernment counseling is appropriate for your situation according to what you've told me. The next step is for your partner and me to chat about their take on the situation and whether they are interested in discernment counseling. What might be a good idea for you is to tell your partner that we talked today, and point her to the website that describes discernment counseling. Further, you can tell them that if they are interested in doing this work, they can contact me directly and we can have a similar conversation to the one you and I just had. What is important here is that no one feels coerced to be part of this process. By putting the ball squarely in their court, they can demonstrate their willingness to do discernment counseling by initiating the call. "
Respect the autonomy of each person to engage in this process at their own pace.


The phone intake is to describe, in sufficient detail, the purpose, goals, and process of discernment counseling.
"The goal of discernment is to help couples arrive at greater clarity and confidence in their decision making about the future of their marriage based on a deeper understanding of the problems in the marriage and each person's contributions to them. "
"Discernment counseling is typically a brief counseling modality and could last anywhere between one and five sessions. There is no need to commit to all five sessions because each of you would only commit to attending one session at a time. "
"The format of the sessions consists of meeting as a couple with the counselor as well as having some time dedicated to one-on-one work with the counselor. After each one-on-one portion of the session, each partner will summarize what he or she is 'taking with them' from the time with the counselor and share it with the partner who was waiting outside the room. The first session is 2 hours, and subsequent sessions are an hour and a half each. "
"In discernment counseling, we discuss the paths that are before every couple on the brink of divorce. Path 1 we call the status quo path and represents your relationship continuing the way it current is. Path 2 represents the separation or divorce path. Path 3 is the possible reconciliation path, in which the couple agrees to take divorce off the table for a 6-month period of couples therapy, and each one commits to work on the relationship to see whether they can get the relationship to a healthier place. These three paths frame the discussions we have in discernment counseling."
"Discernment counseling is different from typical marriage counseling. The goal is not to solve your problems but to help you decide whether to try to solve your problems or choose a different path. It's not about immediate change in your relationship but seeing what changes each of you might need to make in the future if you decide to work on yourselves and your marriage."
Finally, you can end this portion of the phone intake by asking how this process sounds to them and whether they are still interested on the basis of what you have discussed: "Does this sound like a process that might hold some value for you in your current situation?"


We are mostly concerned with is whether one of the partners is feeling coerced to participate and whether participating in discernment counseling will put one of the partners at risk of IPV.
- "We want to make sure everyone who participates in discernment counseling does so voluntarily and that no one is put at risk. So I have a few questions that we ask everyone who contacts us for an appointment.
- Are you feeling pressured by your spouse to participate in this project? Yes / No.
- If yes, does the pressure seem coercive (for example, is it accompanied by threats with personal or legal ramifications)? Yes / No
- Have you or your spouse ever had an order of protection from a court? Yes / No
- If yes, who?
- My last questions are about what happens when you and your partner get into arguments or fights. Again, our goal is to make sure everyone is safe.
- Has your partner ever done something to you out of anger that has caused you physical pain, bruises, or bodily injury? Yes / No (If yes, get specifics)
- Do you ever feel afraid of your spouse? Yes / No
- If yes, are you in danger now? Yes / No
- If yes to either, I can help you talk to someone at an agency that can help you. Would you like me to give you that information? In an emergency, urge the person to call 911. Ask if you can call back to check on the person.
“Leaning In or Out Measure.png” could not be found.


We strongly recommend a 2-hour block of time because of the amount of ground to be covered in the session. After both partners' perspectives are heard in response to a series of questions, the discernment counselor meets one-on-one with both members of the couple, and each briefly shares what he or she learned in the individual conversations. The session ends with the couple in the room together for a summary of the work that was done that day and any impressions the discernment counselor has to share. If both spouses agree, the second discernment counseling session is then scheduled.


In this first meeting together, each person is asked to share their own and listen to the other’s views on how the relationship got to the point where divorce is a possibility, how they have tried to fix the problems they have identified, and how their children (if any) play a role in their decision making. They are also asked to provide a brief account of a time when things were going well in the relationship.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mixed-Agenda Couples
item.description:
These are couples in which one spouse is seriously considering divorce and is reluctant to try couples therapy (but does show up for the first session) while the other spouse wants to preserve the marriage and is eager to start couples therapy.
We refer to the first spouse as leaning-out and the second as leaning in.
Discernment Counseling creates a holding environment for the couple to develop clarity and confidence in deciding on the next step for their relationship, whether it is divorce or a shared commitment to couples therapy to repair the relationship.

item.title: Attentional Bias
item.description: Paying more attention to stimuli that appear threatening; difficulty noticing anything else other than the perceived threatening stimuli; neutral stimuli is considered dangerous (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 130)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Behavioral Avoidance
item.description: Occurs when an individual avoids the stimuli or situations that trigger a fear response. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 130)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Behavioral Inhibition (BI)
item.description: A Temperament style that is characterized by withdrawal, fearfulness, and avoidance of novel situations or unfamiliar people and avoidance of novel situations or interacting socially.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cognitive Avoidance
item.description: Cognitive Avoidance is when someone avoids any thoughts or images. Cognitive avoidance includes behaviors such as avoiding thinking about the worry and engaging in distraction to avoid thinking about the worry.

item.title: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM)
item.description:
The handbook used by health care professionals in the US and much of the world as the authoritative guide to the diagnosis of mental disorders
DSM contains descriptions, symptoms, and other criteria for diagnosing mental disorders.
It also provides a common language for researchers to study the criteria for potential future revisions and to aid in the development of medications and other interventions.


Used universally with
Guidelines for disorders
Not a 'perfect mirror of nature'
Imperfect because there is more to understand through research.
Right now, it is a culmination of mental disorders, a dictionary used to communicate with administrators, clients, and clinicians.
Provide a shared language among professionals and clients.
Most up to date information to provide help and assistance
Clinical judgement, DSM is a 'part' of diagnosis. It must be used with clinical judgement. (What does 'clinical judgement' mean?)
We should not be using the DSM too rigidly, but providing the help our clients need.
Problem:
People who should take it least seriously is scientists.
Cannot make the psychiatric progress clients need.


1840:
Category 'insanity' first attempt to quantify and name psychiatric diagnoses
1844:
APA published a predecessor of the DSM:
A classification of institutionalized mental patients
Early 1900's
First description of schizophrenia by Emil Kraeplin
1917:
Statistical Manual for the Use of Institutions for the insane, including 22 diagnoses.
1952:
First DSM, 130 pages long, 106 disorders
1994:
DSM-IV, 886 pages long, 297 disorders
2000:
DSM-IV-TR, 943 pages long, 365 disorders
2013:
DSM-5, 991 pages long, 157 disorders
2022:
DSM-5-TR, 1050 pages long


Standardizes billing and coding
Standardizes diagnoses and treatment
Guides research
Guides treatment


Oversimplifies human behavior
Increases risk of misdiagnosis or over-diagnosis
Provides labels, which can be stigmatizing


Growing scientific evidence favors dimensional diagnosis of mental disorders
Takes into account individual subjective report of symptom experience and clinician interpretation
Integrates both objective and subjective data to enhance the accuracy


Categorical:
A categorical approach to assessment relied on diagnostic criteria to determine the presence or absence of disruptive or other abnormal behaviors, whereas a dimensional approach places such behaviors on a continuum of frequency and/or severity.
Presence or absence
Yes or no
Dimensional:
Frequency:
None of the time to all of the time
Hourly, daily, weekly, monthly
Intensity/Severity:
Absent 0, mild 1, moderate 2, severe 3
Duration:
How long does it last?
First (Categorical):
Yes / no
Second (Frequency):
How often?
Third (Intensity/Severity):
Rating (Mild, moderate, severe)
Fourth (Duration):
How long does it last?
Growing scientific evidence favors dimensional diagnosis of mental disorders.
Takes into account individual subjective report of symptom experience and clinician interpretation.
Integrates both objective and subjective data to enhance the accuracy of the diagnostic process.
Integrates measures administered at initial interview and over time to track symptom status and response to treatment.


Disorder-specific and correspond closely to the diagnostic criteria.
Some are self-completed by the individual, couple, or family.
Interpreted by the clinician
Shared back with the individual, couple, or family
Others require a clinician to complete.


A generic assessment instrument for health and disability.
Used across all diseases, including mental, neurological, and addictive disorders.
Short, simple and easy to administer (5 to 20 minutes)
Applicable in both clinical and general population settings.
A tool to produce standardized disability levels and profiles.
Applicable across cultures, in all adult populations.
Directly linked at the level of concepts to the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF)


The reason for the assessment, including the member's:
Perception of the condition
Description of symptoms (including reason for referral)
History of mental health treatment (including review of member's records)
Important developmental incidents
Maltreatment, trauma or abuse issues
History of alcohol and drug usage and treatment
Health history and family health history, including physical, chemical and mental health history
Cultural influences and their impact on the member


An assessment of the member's needs based on:
Baseline measurements
Symptoms
Behavior
Skills
Abilities
Resources
Vulnerabilities
Safety
Assessment methods and use of standardized assessment tools
Clinical summary, including recommendations and prioritization of needed mental health or other services
Involvement of the member and member's family in the assessment and his or her preferences or referrals to services.
Sufficient data to support findings on all axes of the current Diagnostic and Statistic Manual (DSM), and any differential diagnosis.



We don't truly have systemic diagnoses in the US context
The medical model warrants an INDIVIDUAL (identified patient/client)
Diagnoses are listed by INDIVIDUAL
Diagnostic criteria for relational problems are needed.


M


The relationship comes first
Making a diagnosis is a team effort
Open-ended and check-list questions
Use screeners/questions to hone in on the diagnosis
Pay attention to clinical significance
Risk/benefit analysis of diagnosis
Understand comorbidity
Be cautious about 'other' categories
Document your thinking
Remember the stakes are high
item.guid: Glossary/Diagnosis/Key Terms and Concepts/Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Emotionality
item.description: The tendency to become emotionally aroused. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 129)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Lifetime Prevalence
item.description: The percentage of individuals who meet criteria for a disorder at any point during their lifetimes. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 128)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Point Prevalence
item.description: the percentage of individuals who meet criteria for a disorder during a specific period of time. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 128)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Temperament
item.description:
An individual's early innate expression of biological, behavioral, and emotional responses to the environment. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 129)
Most temperaments are inherited, and family members are also likely to have similar temperaments. Parents are likely to model and reinforce their child's tendency toward BI or emotionality. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 129)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Accepting Concerns
item.description: Worry relating to potential rejection of one's sexual identity
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Biological Sex
item.description:
The physical sex characteristics you are born with and develop including genitalia, chromosomes, hormones, etc.
Generally assigned at birth and often categorized as male, female, or Intersex.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cognitive Biases Codex
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Concealment Motivation
item.description: Being concerned with protecting one's sexual identity
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Competence
item.description:
Familiarity with and, more important, sensitivity to other peoples' ways of doing things. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
The awareness, knowledge, and skills needed to function effectively with culturally diverse populations.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Encapsulation
item.description: Counselors who are culturally unaware and who operate in isolation from a broader cultural context.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Formulation Interview
item.description:
Provides a framework to assist clinicians in assessing the cultural identity of the affected individual, perceptions of the distress (including how the cultural group of the client would view the problem), psychosocial stressors and 'cultural features of vulnerability and resilience,' and cultural aspects of both the client and the clinician that might impact treatment.
Viewing culture therapeutically includes a perceptual expansion of cultural groups to include age, gender, sexual orientation, religion, language, occupation, military service, social networks, substance use, migration status, geographical region, relationship status (i.e., married or divorced), and not simply race and ethnicity.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Humility
item.description:
The ability to maintain an interpersonal stance that is other-oriented (or open to other) in relation to aspects of cultural identity that are most important for the client. Culturally humble therapists rarely assume competence. Requires the therapist to engage in self-reflection and self-critique.
A complementary component to cultural competence associated with an open attitudinal stance or a multiculturally open orientation to work with diverse clients.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Oppression
item.description: When members of the dominant culture impose their standards upon culturally diverse populations without regard for differences.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Racism
item.description: Imagined, constructed, and allusive distinctions (not based on ascribed physical markers) among social groups provide a reasonable basis for racial and ethnic superiority and, therefore, justify incorrectly the systematically and pervasively unequal relations.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Responsiveness
item.description: An approach that takes into consideration and responds to the cultural values, lifestyles, strengths and assets of the client as they interact with the wider society.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Culture
item.description:
Shared patterns of behavior and experience derived from settings in which people live. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
A system or web of sharing meaning, shared understanding, and shared sense making.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Difficult Process
item.description: How difficult one's sexual identity development was.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Equality
item.description: Treating everyone the same (aims to promote fairness)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Equity
item.description: Giving everyone what they need to be successful (may appear unfair)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ethnocentric Monoculturalism
item.description:
Refers to a belief in the superiority of one's group's cultural heritage over another, and the implications of those standards upon the less powerful group.
Cultural Encapsulation:
Cultural Encapsulation



Counselors who are culturally unaware and who operate in isolation from a broader cultural context.
Cultural Racism:
Cultural Racism



Imagined, constructed, and allusive distinctions (not based on ascribed physical markers) among social groups provide a reasonable basis for racial and ethnic superiority and, therefore, justify incorrectly the systematically and pervasively unequal relations.

Belief in the Superiority of the Dominant Group
Belief in the Inferiority of Others
Power to Impose Standards
Manifestation in Institutions
The Invisible Veil
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Experiential Intersectionality
item.description:
The experience of being a member of more than one social group that cannot be decomposed into the experience of being a member of each.
Example:
The experience of being a Black woman is not just the experience of being Black and the experience of being a woman.
The experience of being a Black woman is a proper compound of the two.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: External Locus of Control
item.description: Attribute success or failure to luck or chance, a higher power, or the influence of another person.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender
item.description:
The result of socially constructed ideas about the behavior, actions, and roles a. particular sex performs.
Term used to exemplify the attributes that a society or culture constitutes as 'masculine' or 'feminine'
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender Expression
item.description: External appearance of one's gender identity, usually expressed through behavior, clothing, haircut or voice, and which may or may not conform to socially defined behaviors and characteristics typically associated with being either masculine or feminine.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender Fluid
item.description: A person who does not identify with a single fixed gender; of or relating to a person having or experiencing a fluid or unfixed gender identity.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender Identity
item.description: One's innermost concept of self as male, female, a blend of both or neither - how individuals perceive themselves and what they call themselves. One's gender identity can be the same or different from their sex assigned at birth.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender Non-Conforming
item.description: A broad term referring to people who do not behave in a way that conforms to the traditional expectations of their gender, or whose gender expression does not fit neatly into a category.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender-Expansive
item.description: Conveys a wider, more flexible range of gender identity and/or expression than typically associated with the binary gender system.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: High-Context (HC) Communication
item.description:
Anchored in the physical context (situation) or internalized in the person.
HC communication relies heavily on non-verbals, and the group identification/understanding shared by those communicating.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Affirmation
item.description: The association of positive thoughts with one's sexual identity
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Centrality
item.description: How central one's sexual identity is to one's overall identity
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Politics
item.description:
A tendency for people of a particular religion, race, social background, etc., to form exclusive political alliances, moving away from traditional broad-based party politics.
Rather than organizing solely around belief systems, programmatic manifestos, or party affiliation, identity political formations typically aim to secure the political freedom of a specific constituency marginalized within its larger context. Members of that constituency assert or reclaim ways of understanding their distinctiveness that challenge dominant oppressive characterizations, with the goal of greater self-determination.
Identity politics shifts out moral and political attention from individual wrongful acts against individuals - perhaps motivated by prejudiced attitudes or bigotry - to structural and systematic injustice against social groups.
This process of recognizing as social and systematic that was formerly perceived as isolated and individual has also characterized the identity politics of marginalized groups (i.e., racial ethnic minorities and LGBTQ persons)
For all these groups, identity-based politics has been a source of strength, community, and intellectual development.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Superiority
item.description: How favorable one views sexual minorities compared to heterosexual people
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Uncertainty
item.description: How uncertain one is concerning their sexual identity.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ideological Oppression
item.description: Any oppressive system has at its core the idea that one group is somehow better than another, and in some measure has the right to control the other group. This idea gets elaborated in many ways - more intelligent, harder working, stronger, more capable, more noble, more deserving, more advanced, chosen, normal, superior, and so on. The dominant group holds this idea about itself. And, of course, the opposite qualities are attributed to the other group - stupid, lazy, weak, incompetent, worthless, less deserving, backward, abnormal, inferior, and so on.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Institutional Oppression
item.description:
The idea that one group is better than another group and has the right to control the other gets embedded in the institutions of the society - the laws, the legal system and police practice, the education system and schools, hiring policies, public policies, housing development, media images, political power, etc.
When a woman makes two thirds of what a man makes in the same job, it is institutionalized sexism. When one out of every four African-American young men is currently in jail, on parole, or on probation, it is institutionalized racism.
When psychiatric institutions and associations 'diagnose' transgender people as having a mental disorder, it is institutionalized gender oppression and transphobia.
Institutional oppression does not have to be intentional.
For example, if a policy unintentionally reinforces and creates new inequalities between privileged and non-privileged groups.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internal Locus of Control
item.description: Believe that the outcomes of their actions are results of their own abilities.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internalized Homonegativity
item.description: The degree to which to which one rejects their sexual identity.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internalized Oppression
item.description:
The fourth way oppression works is within the groups of people who suffer the most from the mistreatment. Oppressed people internalize the ideology of inferiority, they see it reflected in the institutions, they experience disrespect interpersonally from members of the dominant group, and they eventually come to internalize the negative messages about themselves. If we have been told we are stupid, worthless, abnormal, and have been treated as if we were all our lives, then it is not surprising that we would come to believe it. This makes us feel bad.
Oppression always begins from outside the oppressed group, but by the time it gets internalized, the external oppression need hardly be felt for the damage to be done. If people from the oppressed group feel bad about themselves, and because of the nature of the system, do not have the power to direct those feelings back toward the dominant group without receiving more blows, then there are only two places to dump those feelings - on oneself and on the people in the same group. Thus, people in any target group have to struggle hard to keep from feeling heavy feelings of powerlessness or despair. They often tend to put themselves and others down, in ways that mirror the oppressive messages they have gotten all their lives. Acting out internalized oppression runs the gamut from passive powerlessness to violent aggression. It is important to understand that some of the internalized patterns of behavior originally developed to keep people alive - they had real survival value.
On the way to eliminating institutional oppression, each oppressed group has to undo the internalized beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors that stem from the oppression so that it can build unity among people in its group, support its leaders, feel proud of its history, contributions, and potential, develop the strength to challenge patterns that hold the group back, and organize itself into an effective force for social change.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internalized Privilege
item.description: Likewise, people who benefit the most from these systems internalize privilege. Privileged people involuntarily accept stereotypes and false assumptions about oppressed groups made by dominant culture. Internalized privilege includes acceptance of a belief in the inherent inferiority of the oppressed group as well as the inherent superiority or normalcy of one’s own privileged group. Internalized privilege creates an unearned sense of entitlement in members of the privileged group, and can be expressed as a denial of the existence of oppression and as paternalism.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Interpersonal Oppression
item.description:
The idea that one group is better than another and has the right to control the other, which gets structured into institutions, gives permission and reinforcement for individual members of the dominant group to personally disrespect or mistreat individuals in the oppressed group.
Interpersonal racism is what white people do to people of color up close--the racist jokes, the stereotypes, the beatings and harassment, the threats, etc. Similarly, interpersonal sexism is what men do to women - the sexual abuse and harassment, the violence directed at women, the belittling or ignoring of women's thinking, the sexist jokes, etc.
Most people in the dominant group are not consciously oppressive. They have internalized the negative messages about other groups, and consider their attitudes towards the other group quite normal.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Intersex
item.description:
Describes variation in sex characteristics, such as chromosomes, gonads, sex hormones or genitals.
"Intersex," like "Female," and "Male," is a socially constructed category that humans have created to label bodies that they view as different from those they would classify as distinctly 'female' or 'male.'
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Kim Constructive Conversations Model
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Kinesics
item.description:
The term used to refer to bodily movements
Example:
Facial expressions
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Labor Acknowledgement
item.description:
A labor acknowledgement is a statement that recognizes that much of the economic progress and development in a geographic area or industry resulted from the unpaid labor and forced servitude of People of Color - specifically enslaved African labor.
Labor acknowledgements are one way to 'honor and remember the violent histories and legacies of settler colonialism' and to 'collectively begin to acknowledge the historical labor that has allowed our society to get and be where it is today, then we will continue to struggle to reconcile and redress those histories and legacies.' Terah TJ Stewart
Like most modern day US institutions, Solid Ground benefits from the unaddressed legacy of stolen labor at the foundation of this nation and its vast and inequitable wealth.
We respectfully acknowledge our debt to the enslaved people, primarily of African descent, whose labor and suffering built and grew the economy and infrastructure of a nation that refused to recognize their humanity.
While the 13th Amendment to the Constitution technically ended 'slavery' in the US, we know that slavery's ongoing impacts are still felt by countless people forced - through violence, threats, and coercion - to work in the US.
We recognize our debt to exploited workers past and present whose labor was and continues to be stolen through unjust practices.
We acknowledge our collective debt to the Indigenous peoples of this land whose labor was forced and exploited, the Chinese immigrants who built railroads that allowed for westward American development, Japanese Americans whose properties and livelihoods were taken from them while incarcerated during World War II, and migrant workers from the Philippines, Mexico, and Central and South America who have worked Pacific Northwest farms and canneries.
We recognize the immigrant and American-born workers of African, Asian, and Central and South American descent whose labor remains hidden in the shadows but still contributes to the wellbeing of our collective community.
We recognize that our economy continues to rely on the exploited labor of incarcerated people, largely people of color, who earn pennies an hour while generating billions in goods and services each year. And we know there are many other people, too numerous to mention, who are prevented from reaping the true value of their labor by unjust systems and cruel practices.
We mourn their loss of life, liberty, and opportunity.
We acknowledge that the theft of labor is the theft of generational progress. Nearly all people of color have been robbed of the opportunity and wealth that their ancestors might otherwise have passed on to them.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Low-Context (LC) Communication
item.description: Place a greater reliance on the verbal part of the message.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Microaggressions
item.description: Microaggressions are the 'everyday slights, indignities, and insults committed against marginalized groups because of their membership in those groups.'
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Paralanguage
item.description:
Used to refer to other vocal cues that individuals use to communicate
Example:
Volume of voice
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Political Intersectionality
item.description:
This occurs when the political movements working towards justice for different groups, e.g., feminism and antiracism, interact to exclude or marginalize the interests of some subset of the groups, or reinforced another form of injustice.
Examples:
For women of color anti-racist and feminist political agendas often conflict with one another
This is the same for people of color regarding anti-racist and LGBTQ political agendas.
Many times the experience of the dominant group within a targeted population shapes the political agenda.
Therefore, both agendas fail to acknowledge the additional issue of race, patriarchy, or sexual or gender identity and are often inadequate in articulating the full dimensions of racism, sexism, or heterosexism.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Prevention
item.description: The action of stopping something from happening or arising.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Proxemics
item.description:
Refers to perception and the use of personal and interpersonal space.
Example:
Physical closeness or distance when communicating
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Remediation
item.description: The action of remedying something, in particular of reversing or stopping environmental damage.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Representational Intersectionality
item.description:
A concept that refers to the cultural construction of an identity, including the production and the contemporary critiques of the identity.
This occurs when images or tropes are taken to be representative of the group ignore or distort the complexity of the group.
"Representational intersectionality would include both the ways in which these images are produced through a confluence of prevalent narrative of race and gender, as well as the recognition of how contemporary critiques of racist and sexist representations marginalize women of color." (@crenshawMappingMarginsIntersectionality1991, p. 1283)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Sexuality
item.description: Encompasses sex, m gender identities and roles, sexual orientation, eroticism, pleasure, intimacy, and reproduction and is experienced and expressed in thoughts, fantasies, desires, beliefs, attitudes, values, behaviors, practices, roles, and relationships. (World Health Organization, 2006, pg. 10)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Social Context
item.description: Shared meanings that define culture, inform identities, and situate experience. Including the dynamic interconnections of social systems that shape constraints and opportunities within spatial settings.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Structural Intersectionality
item.description:
This occurs when social structures that create and organize different social groups, e.g., gender and race, interact ot produce effects that may not be intended.
Example:
Domestic violence shelters that do not address the multiple needs of poor women, immigrants, and women of color, plausibly also trans women, e.g., by refusing to admit non-English speaking women. Patterns of subordination often intersect in women's experience of domestic violence.
Oftentimes one burden interacts with pre-existing vulnerabilities to create another dimension of disempowerment.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: The Four I's of Oppression
item.description:
Any oppressive system has at its core the idea that one group is somehow better than another, and in some measure has the right to control the other group. This idea gets elaborated in many ways - more intelligent, harder working, stronger, more capable, more noble, more deserving, more advanced, chosen, normal, superior, and so on. The dominant group holds this idea about itself. And, of course, the opposite qualities are attributed to the other group - stupid, lazy, weak, incompetent, worthless, less deserving, backward, abnormal, inferior, and so on.


The idea that one group is better than another group and has the right to control the other gets embedded in the institutions of the society - the laws, the legal system and police practice, the education system and schools, hiring policies, public policies, housing development, media images, political power, etc.
When a woman makes two thirds of what a man makes in the same job, it is institutionalized sexism. When one out of every four African-American young men is currently in jail, on parole, or on probation, it is institutionalized racism.
When psychiatric institutions and associations 'diagnose' transgender people as having a mental disorder, it is institutionalized gender oppression and transphobia.
Institutional oppression does not have to be intentional.
For example, if a policy unintentionally reinforces and creates new inequalities between privileged and non-privileged groups.


The idea that one group is better than another and has the right to control the other, which gets structured into institutions, gives permission and reinforcement for individual members of the dominant group to personally disrespect or mistreat individuals in the oppressed group.
Interpersonal racism is what white people do to people of color up close--the racist jokes, the stereotypes, the beatings and harassment, the threats, etc. Similarly, interpersonal sexism is what men do to women - the sexual abuse and harassment, the violence directed at women, the belittling or ignoring of women's thinking, the sexist jokes, etc.
Most people in the dominant group are not consciously oppressive. They have internalized the negative messages about other groups, and consider their attitudes towards the other group quite normal.


These kinds of oppressive attitudes and behaviors are backed up by the institutional arrangements. This helps to clarify the confusion around what some claim to be "reverse racism." People of color can have prejudices against and anger towards white people, or individual white people. They can act out those feelings in destructive and hurtful ways towards whites. But in almost every case, this acting out will be severely punished. The force of the police and the courts, or at least a gang of whites getting even, will come crashing down on those people of color. The individual prejudice of black people, for example, is not backed up by the legal system and prevailing white institutions. The oppressed group, therefore, does not have the power to enforce its prejudices, unlike the dominant group.
For example, the racist beating of Rodney King was carried out by the institutional force of the police, and upheld by the court system. This would not have happened if King had been white and the officers black.
A simple definition of racism, as a system, is: RACISM = PREJUDICE + POWER.
Therefore, with this definition of the systemic nature of racism, people of color cannot be racist. The same formula holds true for all forms of oppression. The dominant group has its mistreatment of the target group embedded in and backed up by society's institutions and other forms of power.


The fourth way oppression works is within the groups of people who suffer the most from the mistreatment. Oppressed people internalize the ideology of inferiority, they see it reflected in the institutions, they experience disrespect interpersonally from members of the dominant group, and they eventually come to internalize the negative messages about themselves. If we have been told we are stupid, worthless, abnormal, and have been treated as if we were all our lives, then it is not surprising that we would come to believe it. This makes us feel bad.
Oppression always begins from outside the oppressed group, but by the time it gets internalized, the external oppression need hardly be felt for the damage to be done. If people from the oppressed group feel bad about themselves, and because of the nature of the system, do not have the power to direct those feelings back toward the dominant group without receiving more blows, then there are only two places to dump those feelings - on oneself and on the people in the same group. Thus, people in any target group have to struggle hard to keep from feeling heavy feelings of powerlessness or despair. They often tend to put themselves and others down, in ways that mirror the oppressive messages they have gotten all their lives. Acting out internalized oppression runs the gamut from passive powerlessness to violent aggression. It is important to understand that some of the internalized patterns of behavior originally developed to keep people alive - they had real survival value.
On the way to eliminating institutional oppression, each oppressed group has to undo the internalized beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors that stem from the oppression so that it can build unity among people in its group, support its leaders, feel proud of its history, contributions, and potential, develop the strength to challenge patterns that hold the group back, and organize itself into an effective force for social change.


Likewise, people who benefit the most from these systems internalize privilege. Privileged people involuntarily accept stereotypes and false assumptions about oppressed groups made by dominant culture. Internalized privilege includes acceptance of a belief in the inherent inferiority of the oppressed group as well as the inherent superiority or normalcy of one’s own privileged group. Internalized privilege creates an unearned sense of entitlement in members of the privileged group, and can be expressed as a denial of the existence of oppression and as paternalism.


It should be clear that none of these four aspects of oppression can exist separately. As the diagram below suggests, each is completely mixed up with the others. It is crucial at see any oppression as a system. It should also be clear that trying to challenge oppression in any of the four aspects will affect the other three.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Third-Order Change
item.description: A shift in relationship to sociocultural systems that expands possibilities and enables transformation of one's life.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Transgender
item.description: An umbrella term for people whose gender identity and/or expression is different from cultural expectations based on the sex they were assigned at birth. Being transgender does not imply any specific sexual orientation. Therefore, transgender people may identify as straight, gay, lesbian, bisexual, etc.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Worldview
item.description: Composed of people's attitudes, values, and beliefs that affect how people think, define events, make decisions, and behave.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ethics and Cultural Awareness
item.description:
At minimum, therapists need to be culturally attuned in order to work ethically with clients.


@falicovTrainingThinkCulturally1995:
Cultural Framework:
Necessary posture or framework that develops through awareness of the role that values play for families, for therapists, and for their encounter with each other.
Culture:
Sets of shared world views and adaptive behaviors derived from simultaneous membership in a variety of contexts (geography, religion, nationality, ethnicity, race, class, gender, minority status, sexual orientation, occupation, political leanings, migratory patterns, stage of acculturation, values derived from belonging to the same generation, partaking of a single historical moment or particular ideologies)
@murphyEthicsProfessionalIssues2017:
Intersectionality:
An examination of structural, and individual process of power, privilege, and oppression. Privileged and oppressed social identities that interact simultaneously within each individual.
Social justice perspective that emphasizes social position using multiple identities and statuses.
Cultural Competence:
Broadly understood as the ability to work skillfully across cultures, engaging the perspectives and identities of both clinician and patient. Assumed to be about building knowledge of multicultural content areas.
Three main components:
Attitudes and Beliefs:
Knowledge
Skills
Develop an understanding of your own cultural background and how that influences personal attitudes, values, and beliefs.
Develop understanding and knowledge of worldviews of individuals from diverse cultural backgrounds.
Use culturally appropriate interventions.
Cultural Humility:
the ability to maintain an interpersonal stance that is other-oriented (or open to other) in relation to aspects of cultural identity that are most important for the client. Culturally humble therapists rarely assume competence. Requires the therapist to engage in self-reflection and self-critique.
Ability to express respect and lack of superiority even when cultural differences threatened to weaken alliance.
Approach clients with respectful openness, and work collaboratively with clients to understand the unique intersection of clients' various aspects of identities.
It is a disposition rather than a competency per se.
"Culturally humble therapists not only strive to be effective but also cultivate a growing awareness that they are inevitably limited in their knowledge and understanding of a client's cultural background, which motivates them to interpersonally attune themselves to the client in a quest to understand the individual client's cultural background and experience."
Developed a measure of cultural humility from client's perspective, found that it was associated with alliance, and progress, added explained variance to alliance above and beyond cultural competence measure.
Relational Ethics Perspective:
Take responsibility for the way our communication shape others' understandings.
Build relationships based on curiosity, openness, respect, and understanding of the mean making process.
Participate in meaning making in ways that allow for creating inclusive positions.
Understand how our positioning contributes to the creation of social reality.
Transparently share our positions of power and their impact on moral decisions that are made, ideally collaboratively.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Implicit Bias Training
item.description:
Implicit Bias:
The attitudes or stereotypes that affect our understanding, actions, and decisions in an unconscious manner.
Biases can be neutral, positive, or negative.
Operating outside our conscious awareness.
Based on inaccurate information or stereotypes.
Implicit biases can impact our decisions, perceptions, and behaviors.
Actions and decisions resulting from our biases create real world barriers to equity and opportunity.
It is so important to learn about implicit bias, particularly those biases that don't align with your intentions or explicit beliefs.
Implicit bias does NOT refer to those beliefs we conceal or suppress in an effort to appear non-biased.
Implicit bias is a took we possess for understanding.
Stereotype:
Beliefs that are mentally associated with a given category.



Teachers with strong, implicit pro-White biases were more likely to take a 'teach-to-the-test' approach.


Discipline decisions are challenging and stressful for everyone involved.
Differences in discipline show up strongly with regards to race and gender.
Subjective or ambiguous situations can activate implicit associations.
Students of color are more likely to receive disciplinary measures for 'disruptive behavior', 'disrespect', and 'excessive noise.'
Culturally-influenced perceptions of student behavior.
Implicit bias can turn even our best intentions into unwanted outcomes.


Research is growing around the role of implicit bias in limiting opportunities.
The race, gender, and program affiliation of the professor did not have an overall impact on the response. They responded better to White men.



It is extremely difficult - if not impossible - to uncover our implicit biases through introspection.
There are two ways to measure implicit biases:
Examining our behavior
Neurological measurement
Medical brain scanning technology

Where this occurs the errors are said to be autocorrelated.

item.title: Bayesian Statistics
item.description:
A method of statistical inference named after Thomas Bayes, an 18th-century English mathematician. The method involves working backwards from effect to cause, by estimating the conditional probability of a cause given that certain events have occurred. Bayesian inference involves using new information, called the posterior probability, to revise earlier estimates of probability, called Prior Probability.

item.title: Correlation
item.description:
The statistical association between two variables measured at ordinal, interval or ratio level. Many different 'correlation co-efficients' are used as measures of association.


We already know many ways to represent the association between two variables, both measured on at least an interval scale.
Scatterplot
Covariance sxy = (∑i = 1n (x1 - x-bar)(yi - y-bar)) ÷ n - 1 (𝜎xy for population)
Pearson correlation coefficient rxy = (sxy) ÷ (sxsy) (𝜌xy for population)
The correlation reflects the noisiness and direction of a linear relationship, but not the slope of that relationship, nor many aspects of non-linear relationships.




To test whether the sample correlation between x and y is significantly different from zero (non-directional):
H0: 𝜌 = 0 vs. H1: 𝜌 ≠ 0
Directional alternatives are also possible.
Assumptions:
Linearity:
The Pearson correlation assumes that the relationship among x and y is a linear relationship.
Independence:
Units or cases are randomly sampled from the population.


tobs = r√(n - 2) ÷ (1 - r2)
tcrit: Given the 𝛼 level, t distribution with degrees of freedom (df = n - 2)
Reject H0 if tobs > tcrit (or for negative values: tobs < tcrit)
Alternatively, reject H0 if p < 𝛼
APA Style Writing Template:
A Pearson correlation coefficient was computed to assess the linear relationship between x and y. There was a (weak / moderate / strong negative / positive) correlation between x and y, r (df) = (p-value).
Notice:
No need to report t.


Restricting the range of scores on one or both variables will reduce the strength of a correlation.
If the size of the standard deviation for one variable is reduced, everything else being equal, then the size of correlations with other variables will also be reduced. In other words, we need sufficient variation for a relationship to be evidenced through the correlation coefficient value.
HS GPA and ACT example:
The strength of correlation between GPA and ACT will be lessened if we only focus on the graduates with summa cum laude (weighted GPA 4.2 or above).


Correlation means the variables are related in some way, but correlations alone should not be used to infer cause. A high correlation between x and y might be a result of:
x causes y
y causes x
A third variable z is causing both x and y (or even more variables are involved).
Causality is not easy to prove. Application of complex statistical methods is not evidence for causality!
Causation (x -> y) can only be inferred (formalized by the 19 th-century philosopher John Stuart Mill) if:
x proceeded y
x was related to y
We can find no other plausible alternative explanation for the effect on y other than x.


'Ballpark' estimates for Pearson correlation coefficient r:
r = ± .2 (weak)
r = ± .4 (moderate)
r = ± .8 (strong)
It also depends on the nature of variables, studies, and fields (literature review).
Cohen's (1988) standards for Pearson correlation coefficient r:
r = ± .1 (weak)
r = ± .3 (moderate)
r = ± .5 (strong)




Correlation does not imply causation. With proper literature review and research design, however we can investigate how one variable (x or IV) explains the variability (variance) in the other variable (y or DV). If x is indeed a significant predictor of y, we can use x to predict y.
Still a bivariate analysis, but with a different goal in mind. For example, the school district might want to use GPA to explain the variable in ACT scores and use GPA to predict ACT.
Here we have only one predictor (IV) in the model: Simple Linear Regression (SLR).
You will learn regression models with multiple predictors, multiple linear regression (MLR), in more advanced stats classes.
Regression means you are trying to find a pattern between x and y. You are using x to predict y. We are only using one.




If we square the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between x and y, r2 indicates the proportion of the Variance in y that can be explained by x.
HS GPA and ACT example: r = .698
Square it:
r2 = (. 698)2 ≈ .487
This indicates 48.7% of the variance in ACT scores can be explained (or accounted for) by GPA.
Recall r ranges from -1 to 1. What does it mean for the range of r2?
Recall 'ballpark' effect size:
Weak (|r| ≥ .2)
Weak (r2 ≥ .04 or 4%)
Moderate (|r| ≥ .4)
Moderate (r2 ≥ .16 or 16%)
Strong (|r| ≥ .8)
Strong (r2 ≥ .64 or 64%)


xi: IV data point for subject i
yi: DV data point for subject i
yi: Expected/predicted value for subject i (i.e., the regression line)

𝛽0: Intercept (Constant)
𝛽1: Slope (How much DV increases as IV increases by 1 unit)


Finding b0 and b1 (regression coefficients) for the regression line:

Best estimates for b's are the ones that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. Working with the squared values, our goal is to find estimate b0 and b1 to minimize the error sum of squares:
SSE =
The optimal solution:
b0 = y-hat - b1x-bar
Regression line goes through both means of x and y!
The slope is determined by the correlation between x and y with a scale of y per change in x.


Analyze -> Regression -> Linear
Define DV and IV (one IV for SLR)
Usually you'd already review descriptive statistics and correlations before running a regression, but you can also ask SPSS to report Descriptive in the Statistics option.
Many other options are for MLR only.
The default SPSS output has 3 sections:
Model Summary (How much variance in DV is explained by the model)
ANOVA Table (Model significance)
Regression Coefficients (Equation for the regression line)


Total variability (variance) in DV is partitioned into two parts:
What we can explain by the model (regression)
What we still cannot explain (error)
Regression sum of squares (SSR)
Error Sum of Squares (SSE)
Total Sum of Squares (SSTO)
SSTO = SSR + SSE
SSR, SSE, and SSTO are available in the ANOVA table


R2 indicates the proportion of variance in DV explained (accounted for) by the model, which can be considered the overall model fit.
R2 = (SSR) ÷ (SSTO) = 1 - (SSE ÷ SSTO) = (Multiple R)2
In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y
Multiple R is the correlation between yi and y-hati (always positive)
In SLR, Multiple R = | rxy |


Omnibus:
Comprising several items
"Congress passed an omnibus anticrime package."
The omnibus test is used to evaluate the significance of overall regression model. Statistics used to conduct the omnibus test are available in the ANOVA table.
Many different (equivalent) ways to represent the omnibus test, but they are asking the same question:
Is the regression model good enough to be used to explain/predict DV?
Since we are comparing variances (SSR and SSE), the sample statistics is compared to a critical F statistics, given the significance level (usually α=. 05). General idea:
Large observed F means much variance in DV can be explained by the model (desired)!


H0: β1 = 0
H1: β1 ≠ 0
H0: y-hat = y-bar
H1: y-hat = b0 +b1x (DV cannot be predicted by model)
H0: ρ = 0 (ρ is the population correlation between model and data, estimated by Multiple R)
H1: ρ > 0
H0: ρ2 = 0
H1: ρ2 > 0




Compare Fobs to the critical F(1, n -2)
Reject H0 if Fobs > F(1, n -2)
Alternatively, reject H0 if p < α
For APA style writing, make sure you report the F statistic along with both degrees of freedom and the p-value.

item.title: Multicollinearity
item.description:
In Multiple Linear Regression (MLR) multicollinearity is said to exist when two or more of the independent variables are themselves highly correlated, a situation that makes it difficult to establish the effect each has on the dependent variable.
How to Check
Calculate the Variance Inflation Factor (VIF).
Values above 5-10 indicate multicollinearity.
Example
Check if square footage and number of bedrooms are highly correlated.
Solution
Remove or combine correlated variables.


Autocorrelation
